I would also like to take this opportunity to emphasize that the coming reform of the common agricultural policy basically demands, and reinforces the need for, the attribution of sufficient weight to environmental questions, also in the light of this sustainable development strategy to which we have pledged our support. We must also underline the role of the Structural and Cohesion Funds in developing environmental policy, particularly this link between the environment and employment.

There is no doubt, for example, that the rule that 50 % of the Cohesion Fund must be applied to the environment has contributed very positively to improving the quality of life in the Cohesion states, but it has also increased the amount of environmental investment in the Cohesion states, making the link between the role of the environment and job creation more obvious.

In addition, it is now generally acknowledged that the sectors and companies that are investing in ecological processes, production systems and products will find themselves less and less able to compete within the European Union and in trade between the Union and third countries. This is why we are declaring our support for Mrs Hulthén's report, and also why we challenge the Commission to submit some practical proposals, after this communication, in line with the report Committee on the Environment of the European Parliament.

  Virgin (PPE). – (SV) Madam President, we are now discussing a good report which contains a lot of good ideas for the Commission to work on. I would like to congratulate Mrs Hulthén on this.

The report raises important questions about how environmental policy can contribute to creating new, meaningful jobs in the EU. As data from the Commission's communication shows, the environmental sector is expanding strongly with an estimated growth in the coming years of 5.5 %. This is very pleasing. The explanation is partly peoples' increasing commitment to environmental issues. This changes their demand towards environmentally friendly goods and thus strengthens employment in the environmental sector. Political decisions on emission limits, etcetera, have yielded results in the form of investments and therefore jobs.

Yesterday we had a debate on financial instruments. If they are used in the right way, they can undeniably contribute to a better environment and increased employment. However, excessive use or defective environmental charges risk having the opposite effect. I also believe it is important to stress the fact that growth has an important function in this context. With increased growth the opportunities for us to invest in a better environment increase. That is exactly what is happening. Growth in our modern society is coming through new sectors. The environment is undeniably in the front line.

The European Council's recommendations on how we can increase employment in Europe are clearly closely linked to the subject we are discussing this evening. Some of these ideas are expressed in the amendments proposed by the PPE Group. I hope that the rapporteur will be able to support all these proposals if she is allowed to sleep on it.

  González Álvarez (GUE/NGL). – (ES) Mr President, we agree with Mrs Hulthén"s report and the opinions of the Committee on Regional Policy and the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. In the opinion of the Committee on Regional Policy, in fact, confirmation is given of something that is very clear: “the patterns of production and consumption today are far from sustainable’, as stated clearly in the fifth action programme on the environment. And naturally, the industrialized countries are essentially responsible today for the environmental situation in the world.

In the Amsterdam Treaty, employment is linked to the environment, and these two sectors are linked to the remaining policies. Yet we all know that decisions on economic and agricultural issues are adopted that have nothing to do with the protection of the environment.

Therefore, we are in complete agreement that local and regional authorities should participate where projects related to the Structural Funds and the environment are involved. We also support the use of those people who, in some regions of the European Union, come from industry and who could receive training to allow them to work, in fact, in jobs treating water, treating waste, treating contaminated land and caring for natural areas.

As the OECD rightly states, the environment sector is a sector which might experience a growth of 5.5 % in the coming years in terms of generating employment. We are not used to seeing other sectors with such a level of growth; it is more usual to see a decline. It is, therefore, essential to link employment and the environment.

  Schörling (V). – (SV) Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mrs Hulthén on an excellent report on two very important and pressing themes, namely, the environment and employment. Information from Eurostat shows that we have around 3.5 million environment‐related jobs in the EU today. We also have the modest estimate from the OECD of an annual increase in environment‐related jobs of 5.5 %. This shows quite clearly that the combination of necessary environmental investments and ‚green jobs’ is not only good economics, but also a way to combine underused human resources and overused natural resources.

Since Commissioner Bjerregaard is here at this late hour, which I really appreciate, I would like to urge the Commission to approve as soon as possible Sweden's action plan for employment and ‚green jobs’ which has been waiting for approval from the Commission since November. Otherwise, the signals from the Commission will be very contradictory.

Naturally, my group is going to support this report, but we would appreciate it if we also received support for our amendment, which I consider to be an important addition to paragraph 45, that is, that the countries which want to introduce a tax on energy and a carbon dioxide tax should take a lead and show the other countries what can be done to fulfil the commitments which were made in Kyoto.

  Taubira‐Delannon (ARE). – (FR) Madam President, Commissioner, after so many years spent preaching to, and so much energy deployed in convincing, the developing countries that they should abandon the wasteful growth example of the North and commit themselves resolutely to the ascetic path of sustainable development, the European Union has realized that it, too, could do with sweeping its own back yard and admit that persistent unemployment and massive exclusion are not sustainable ways of life.

Does this mean that we are abandoning our wonder at productivist technologies, so voracious in their use of natural resources and so misanthropic? Are we now recognizing that the aim of development is an improvement in living conditions, a reduction in inequalities and the mass diffusion of knowledge? Are we now going to place the people at the heart of this development dynamic?

The environment is transverse. Upstream it feeds on policies of growth, education, training, and employment; policies of public health, taxation, promotion and the labelling of public services. Downstream it expresses the stable emergence of the environmental conditions in the fields of energy, transport, agriculture, industry and tourism. Cooperation policy should generate policies of co‐development. However, we must not sink into otherworldliness. We know that, in the short term, there will be no net creation of jobs on a large scale.

In addition, integrating the environment into economic policies often amounts to incorporating new costs. Taxing pollution sometimes creates competitiveness differentials, thus destroying jobs. We must, nevertheless, continue to move forward. In order to do this, in order to reduce these risks and to control these perverse effects, we must envisage a global environmental and employment policy. It is the only way of establishing a level of coordination which will make all efforts promoting the environment and employment both just and efficient. For this, clear objectives are needed, and undoubtedly financial means which are more substantial than the mere mention of Structural Funds.

  Graenitz (PSE). ‐ (DE) Madam President, I would have liked to say that there was once a time when people believed that the environment destroyed employment. But it was not long ago that this way of thinking prevailed. Today, everyone has realized that it is only by respecting natural resources and using raw materials and energy economically and carefully that jobs can be secured in the long term and thus sustainable development can be introduced.

I think it is very important that the Commission has submitted its statement on the environment and employment to Parliament this year, after careful preparation by means of a hearing, and that we are discussing it now, at the beginning of the Austrian presidency, which will deal with ways in which national employment projects can be implemented. I thank Mrs Hulthén, the rapporteur, for the competent way in which she took on and prepared this report.

We certainly still have a great deal to do in order to translate into concrete terms the issue of which jobs can be created where, not to create too many jobs by means of repairing the environment, where there is still plenty to be done, but in particular to create jobs where new industries are working on preparing for more environmentally friendly operations and creating the necessary infrastructure. Even in the Kyoto process, if it is a question of the reduction of emissions, in this area it will also be a question of jobs because due to the thermal insulation alone in buildings which already exist, many states will only be able to achieve half the necessary reduction in emissions.

Commissioner, I hope that the issue of the environment and employment will play a particularly important role in the debate which will take place in the next six months.

  Bjerregaard, Member of the Commission. – (DA) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I totally agree with the view expressed by the rapporteur and the delegates during today"s debate: that we are discussing a very important topic, and therefore it is of course a matter of irritation that it has come up so late in the day. But that must not prevent us from studying the importance of the relationship between environmental protection and employment.

Firstly, allow me to address employment, because employment is now clearly included as an item on the agenda of the European Union. We know that employment was included in the Amsterdam Treaty as a goal for the Union. We held a extraordinary summit on employment last year in Luxembourg, and this year, for the first time, all 15 Member States have presented their action plans on employment to the Commission. The Commission presented an initial evaluation of these plans at the Cardiff Summit, giving us the opportunity to scrutinize these policies from an environmental point of view and to discuss with our colleagues how to promote the existing synergies between the two policies.

One way of doing so would be to integrate the objective of environmental protection and sustainable development into the new 1999 employment guidelines. As regards environmental protection, European commitment dates back further, and many have mentioned this, but it was of course given new momentum at the Cardiff Summit, where a reinforced strategy for integrating the environment into all other EU policies was approved.

Today, we are not only linking economics and the environment. We are also adding a social dimension to sustainable development. Balanced economic growth, environmental protection and job creation are not only mutually compatible; they are building blocks of long‐term development strategy. In order to implement this new development model, there are certain principles – as outlined in the declaration – that must be adhered to, and I will briefly mention some of these. We need environmentally‐oriented investment. We need higher levels of employment, and by that I mean we need a change in fiscal legislation – which, as Mr Virgin mentioned, we have also debated this evening, and almost just as late at that – by shifting taxation away from the workforce. Finally, we need the involvement of all interested parties.

In connection with climate problems, I can see a number of possibilities in particular for creating jobs in new industries and services, whether it is a question of expanding the application of renewable energy sources, improving energy efficiency in terms of processes, products and buildings, or increased exports to markets beyond the Union. All this would save money. It would improve the environment and create jobs. I agree with Mrs Graenitz in that it is very gratifying to see that the Austrian presidency will be addressing the declaration on the environment and employment at the Environment Council in October. I hope the Council will take that opportunity to adopt a resolution that would serve to strengthen the commitment of the Commission and the Member States to take further steps in the areas of the environment and employment.

Madam President, I will stop here, but before I do so, I would like to express my appreciation to the three committees of the European Parliament for their excellent work on the report and their statements on the Commission"s declaration on the environment and employment. In particular, I would like to thank Mrs Hulthén for the terrific job she has done as rapporteur, and I would also like to thank Mr Ken Collins, chairman of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Protection, for his active participation in the conference on the environment and employment hosted jointly by the European Parliament and the Commission last year. And finally, I would just also like to express my satisfaction with the productive collaboration I have enjoyed with my colleague Padraig Flynn.

  President . – Thank you, Commissioner Bjerregaard.

The debate is closed.

The vote will take place tomorrow at 12.00 noon.(1)

(The sitting was closed at 00.05 a.m.)

ANNEX

1. Questions to the Council

 

Question No 15 by Nuala Ahern (H−0638/98)

Subject: Proposed measures by Council on the unacceptable risks to citizens and the environment posed by nuclear plants

What steps will the Council take during Austria's presidency to intervene in cases such as Mochovce in Slovakia and Sellafield in the UK, where nuclear plants pose unacceptable risks to citizens and the environment of neighbouring states?

Question No 16 by Paul Rübig (H−0684/98)

Subject: Safety of nuclear power stations

The debate concerning the Mochovce power station has shown that the utilization of nuclear energy is still a highly charged topic. Our goal must at all events be to put through sensible and effective measures in the interests of the health and safety of all of Europe's citizens.

For this reason, I support the initiative by the President‐in‐Office of the Council to make the safety of nuclear power stations a Europe‐wide issue, since so far no 'acquis communautaire' has been created for this area, let alone any kind of internationally binding agreement. Within the meaning of the subsidiarity provided for in Article 3b of the Treaty, this goal can, because of its scope and significance, be better achieved however at Community level or, where appropriate, beyond.

How does the Presidency intend to take this initiative further?

Joint Answer

1. The Council attaches great importance to the protection of the public against the dangers arising from ionizing radiation and, by extension, to the issue of nuclear safety both inside and outside the Union. In that connection, it pays particular attention to compliance with internationally recognized principles in the sphere of nuclear safety.

Due account is also taken of this matter in the sphere of foreign relations, particularly in relations with the countries of Central Europe in the run‐up to their accession. The principles, priorities and objectives of the accession partnership with Slovakia – which have been notified to Parliament – explicitly stipulate that internationally recognized safety principles must be complied with in connection with the construction of the Mochovce nuclear power station, in the context of a long‐term, comprehensive energy policy strategy based on efficiency and diversification.

It should also be borne in mind that a number of options were open to the Slovak authorities as regards the construction of the two Mochovce reactors under conditions guaranteeing their safety and that they chose a consortium of European undertakings whose experience is acknowledged in the Union.

The Council has regularly monitored developments in connection with the Mochovce power station and has taken the opportunity offered by each meeting to remind the Slovak side of the general importance of nuclear safety. After the Council had been informed, at its meeting of 25 May, about the Austrian Federal Government's concerns regarding the planned entry into service of the Mochovce power station, it once again made its views clear to the Slovak authorities, at the same time expressing its confidence in their competence in the nuclear energy sphere and their close cooperation with the IAEO. In addition, I can inform you that Commissioner VAN DEN BROEK has made similar representations to the Slovak Government.

Against this background, the Council will continue to emphasize the vital need to close down the NPP‐V−1 reactors in Bohunice and the political undertaking to that effect given by the Slovak Government.

2. Moreover, by means of Directive 96/29/Euratom laying down basic safety standards for the protection of the health of workers and the general public against the dangers arising from ionizing radiation the Council has strengthened the key Community legal provision in the sphere of health protection by laying down stricter standards and thereby clearing the way for improved protection. This directive is applicable in all Member States, particularly in connection with the nuclear plants in Sellafield.

All the provisions of Chapter 3 of the Euratom Treaty, dealing with health protection, and Chapter 7, dealing with the monitoring of nuclear plant safety, are likewise applicable throughout the European Union.

3. During the second half of 1998 the Council will consider Commission proposals dealing with the accession of Euratom to the Agreement on Nuclear Safety and the Agreement on the safe disposal of radioactive waste and spent fuel elements; this should ultimately strengthen the Community's role.

The Presidency would like to make clear now that it will do everything in its power to ensure that the Council considers any further Commission proposals with the appropriate degree of urgency.

Question No 17 by Vassilis Ephremidis (H−0640/98)

Subject: Inadmissible US intervention in Cardiff summit meeting discussions

During the summit meeting in Cardiff US President Clinton telephoned the Greek Prime Minister, Mr Simitis, in person in order to exert pressure on Greece to revise its position in respect of EU‐Turkey relations. President Clinton directly linked Turkish accession to the EU with the situation in the Aegean and stressed that tension in the region would mount if Greece remained intransigent.

Will the Council say whether other European Governments have been subject to similar pressure from the US aimed at encouraging them to view Turkey as the twelfth candidate country for EU accession, whether it considers that the direct intervention of a third country in the internal affairs of the European Council is acceptable and whether it disapproves of this position adopted by the US or of attempts by any other third country to influence EU decision‐making both directly and indirectly by crude blackmail in the form of threats of border clashes and conflicts?

Answer

The Council does not involve itself in bilateral talks between a Member State and a third country, unless the Member State in question wishes it to. That was not the case in Cardiff..

Question No 18 by David Martin (H−0641/98)

Subject: Human Rights in Colombia

In the light of continuing reports of human rights violations in Colombia does the Council accept that human rights violations are increasing in Colombia, particularly against human rights defenders, and can the Council outline what representation has been made to the Colombian Government to implement the recommendations made in the Report by the High Commissioner for Human Rights at the 54th Session of the UNCHR in Geneva this year?

Answer

1. The Union has always closely monitored the situation in Colombia, in particular as regards the respect of human rights. In relation to the recent spate of violence preceding the electoral period and in particular the killing of human rights workers the Union made a demarche to the Colombian Government on 29 April, the main lines of which are as follows:

2. The European Union was particularly shocked by the recent murders of prominent and respected personalities active in public life, including Jesus Maria Valle, Maria Arango Fonnegra and Eduardo Umana. The EU unreservedly condemns these killings.

3. The European Union considered that the best deterrent against the continuation of such atrocities would be the arrest and trial of the instigators and perpetrators of such crimes and urged the Colombian authorities to do all they can to bring to justice those responsible for these crimes.

4. EU concern has also been expressed about the threats received by other prominent individuals working for peace and the EU urged the authorities to give the highest priority to providing protection for those people working to promote respect for human rights in Colombia.

5. At the same time, the Union urged the Colombian Government to implement the recommendations made in the High Commission for Human Rights report at the 54th session of the UNHCR held in Geneva this spring.

6. At present, the Union is examining the best way to reinject greater impetus into the peace process after the presidential elections held on 21 June.

Question No 19 by John Cushnahan (H−0646/98)

Subject: Debt problems of developing nations

Given the failure of the G8 Summit, which met in Birmingham recently, to adopt the necessary measures to alleviate the huge debt problems faced by developing nations, will the Council take an initiative on this issue?

Answer

Action on debt relief is primarily a matter for appropriate groups like for instance the Paris Club and International Financial Institutions in particular IMF (International Monetary Fund) and HIPC within the context of the IBRD‐Initiative (International Bank for Reconstruction and Development).

The conclusions reached at the G8 Summit in Birmingham mark a significant step forward, both in recognising the need for progress on debt relief by the year 2000, and in endorsing proposals put forward by the United Kingdom for faster debt relief to post conflict countries in order to release more resources for essential rehabilitation. The G8 also agreed to use export credits for heavily indebted poor countries only for productive expenditure.

Question No 20 by Arthur Newens (H−0654/98)

Subject: Human rights and the death penalty in Trinidad and Tobago

Is the Council aware that Trinidad and Tobago has withdrawn from the American Convention on Human Rights, apparently in order to speed up procedures for the application of the death penalty, and that Trinidad and Tobago has also withdrawn from the First Optional Protocol to the UN International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, in order to re‐accede immediately with a reservation specifically excluding those under sentence of death from petitioning the United Nations Humans Rights Committee? Will the Council make representations to the authorities of Trinidad and Tobago, expressing its dismay at this subversion of important international human rights instruments, press the government of Trinidad and Tobago to reconsider its position, since the death penalty is an unacceptable and barbaric sanction, and make it clear to the UN that it regards such a manoeuvre as discriminatory and in principle a violation of basic human rights enshrined in the ICCPR and therefore wholly unacceptable?

Answer

On 10 June, the presidency, accompanied by all resident EU heads of mission in Trinidad and Tobago, made a demarche to the foreign minister of Trinidad and Tobago. The presidency expressed its grave concern over the announcement by Trinidad and Tobago to withdraw from the First Optional Protocol to the ICCPR and its decision to re‐accede with a reservation excluding the competence of the Human Rights Committee to consider communications relating to the imposition of the death penalty. The EU made it clear that it believes that the rights of persons facing the death penalty are best safeguarded when the right of petition provided for under this protocol is available to them.

The EU has also expressed its concern over the withdrawal from the American Convention on Human Rights, the consequence of which will be that individuals facing the death penalty will have no option to appeal beyond the domestic appeals procedure.

Furthermore, the EU is concerned that this action by Trinidad and Tobago might have a trigger effect on other countries which are currently party to the First Optional Protocol and relevant regional human rights instruments. For these reasons, the EU urged the Trinidad authorities to revoke their decision before the denunciations become effective.

The Trinidad foreign minister responded on various points but gave no indication that there would be a change in the government's position. He said that the purpose of the withdrawals was to enable the law of Trinidad and Tobago to be implemented in respect of the death penalty. He added that the government would have preferred to restrict their action on the American Convention of Human Rights to an exclusion of competence in respect of the death penalty. But there was no provision for that in the convention.

The EU remains concerned over this matter and will continue to call upon the Trinidad and Tobago government to revoke its decision. Meanwhile, the EU will make demarches to the Trinidad and Tobago government whenever it appears an execution is imminent.

Question No 21 by Maj Theorin (H−0656/98)

Subject: Nuclear weapons testing

The nuclear weapons tests conducted by India and Pakistan have opened the way for a new nuclear arms race. Nuclear disarmament must be stepped up, with the USA and Russia bearing the main responsibility. An initiative put together by eight countries including Sweden and Ireland contains proposals, in line with what the Canberra Commission has proposed, for a series of measures designed to reduce the threat from nuclear weapons.

What steps will the Presidency take in response to those proposals?

Answer

The European Union has clearly and publicly stated its position with regard to the nuclear weapons tests conducted by India and Pakistan. The Council sent a statement to this effect to India on 25 May 1998 and to India and Pakistan on 8 June 1998. The European Council, at its meeting in Cardiff on 15 and 16 June 1998, again expressed the EU"s grave concern about the situation in south‐east Asia, pointing out that India and Pakistan, by carrying out these nuclear weapons tests, were threatening the stability of that region and were excluding themselves from the efforts being made by the international community towards the non‐proliferation of nuclear weapons. The European Council has noted that the Member States – and this applies to both States with nuclear capability and to those without – have again affirmed their resolve to comply with the obligations on nuclear disarmament as laid down in Article VI of the Nuclear Non‐Proliferation Treaty. The Council also took note of recent initiatives put together in this area by a number of countries, including Ireland and Sweden.

As the questioner knows, the EU believes that the Nuclear Non‐Proliferation Treaty is the cornerstone of the international Non‐Proliferation Ruling. According to the “principles and objectives’, which were laid down at the Conference on the review and extension of the Non‐Proliferation Treaty held in 1995, the membership of all States continues to be one of the main objectives of all signatories to the Treaty. This objective is a Council priority and in a Common Position taken on 23 April 1998, relating to preparations for the second sitting of the Preparatory Committee for the review conference on the Nuclear Non‐Proliferation Treaty, which is planned for the year 2000, the presidency will be introducing measures to promote the universality of the Non‐Proliferation Treaty.

As part of the third component of the action programme emanating from the decision on “principles and objectives’ the nuclear States are resolved to move systematically and progressively towards the worldwide reduction of nuclear weapons, with the ultimate aim of their complete elimination, and to adopt a policy of general and complete disarmament under strict and effective international scrutiny. In recent statements the European Council has referred to the obligation of Member States to pursue the course of nuclear disarmament.

The presidency in its actions will certainly be guided by the conclusions which have been made by the European Council and by the Common Position adopted on 23 April 1998, as well as by any further statements emanating from the Council as part of its ongoing review of the situation in south‐east Asia.

Question No 22 by James Nicholson (H−0658/98)

Subject: Northern Ireland Objective 1 status

Will the Council accept the conclusion of the House of Commons Trade and Industry Select Committee 7th Report (25/6/98 HC 697) that withdrawal of Objective 1 status from Northern Ireland through an inflexible application of the 75 % of GDP criteria would undermine the EU cohesion policy?

Answer

1. The honourable Member is aware of the fact that in order effectively to concentrate Structural Fund measures in its proposals the Commission has established a definition according to which regions with a per‐capita GDP of less than 75 % of the Community average would be classified as underdeveloped regions. The Commission has also proposed that this criterium should be strictly applied. Moreover, transitionary measures of support are guaranteed for those regions which in 1999 come under priority status and no longer meet the funding criteria.

2. The Council has not yet concluded its review of the Commission"s proposals and has also still to reach a position on the criteria for awarding regions Objective 1 status. The Council therefore considers that it is unable to answer the question which has been put by the honourable Member.

Question No 23 by Paul Lannoye (H−0663/98)

Subject: EU‐USA Agreement

On 18 May an EU‐USA summit concluded with a political agreement which anticipates the provision of the possible forthcoming multilateral agreement on investments (MAI) with regard to expropriation and nationalization.

On 25 May the Council approved this agreement, several of whose provisions describe the concept of expropriation in contravention of international law. On what criteria does the Council consider that international law is infringed when no competent legal authority has issued a ruling?

Does the Council also consider that the principle of the use by both parties of unilateral economic sanctions when it has not been possible to reach a wider agreement or in extremely urgent cases, as provided for in the context of the transatlantic partnership on political cooperation, is compatible with international law?

Answer

1. In the first part of his question the honourable Member is clearly referring to the agreement relating to disciplines for improving investment protection, which are a constituent of the package comprising the Helms‐Burton Law and the Law on sanctions against Iran and Libya, and of which the Council took note on 25 May.

2. In connection with the concept of expropriation of property in contravention of international law, paragraph I (B 1 a) of the agreement refers to a “ruling of an international court of arbitration or final decision by the expropriating State’ and Annex B (3 a) refers to a “court of arbitration’, the “courts of the expropriating State’ or an “administrative procedure in the State, whose nationality is held by the claimant’.

3. According to paragraph I (B 1 b) of the agreement, “arrangements’ have to be worked out in order to establish the legitimacy of expropriations under international law, which have not been judged by a court of law or by a court of arbitration. These “arrangements’ do not yet exist. As far as the European Union is concerned, it is for the Commission to present a proposal as to the usual mode of procedure.

4. As regards the second part of the question I can say that the statement on the “transatlantic partnership on political cooperation’ in no way establishes the principle of “unilateral economic sanctions’. Section 2 g of this text leaves each party open to decide on the imposition of economic sanctions. Were the Council to avail itself of such measures, it would doubtless do so in accordance with international law.

Question No 24 by Alex Smith (H−0667/98)

Subject: EU‐South Africa free trade area negotiations

Could the Presidency assure us of its strong commitment to finalizing the EU‐South Africa FTA negotiations as a matter of priority? Could the Presidency clarify the specific proposals the EU will put forward with regard to:

‐ ensuring a clear position vis‐à‐vis the compensation measures for the BLNS countries who face heavy losses of government revenue;

‐ the form and content of the special protocols aimed at protecting the regional interests of the SADC as a whole;

‐ the process of consultation with our BLNS and other SADC partners before the conclusion of the final agreement;

‐ measures aimed at addressing the exports of subsidized EU food products and their potential distorting effect on the South African market?

Answer

The European Council in Cardiff on 15‐16 June 1998 underlined the Union's determination to bring the negotiations on a comprehensive trade, development and cooperation agreement with South Africa to a successful conclusion no later than the autumn of 1998.

The Austrian presidency will do all in its power to reach this objective within the time limits decided at Cardiff by our Heads of State and Government. In this spirit we will consider the results of the next round of negotiations on a trade and cooperation agreement with South Africa which will take place on 14‐15 July 1998.

Concerning the regional aspects of the negotiations with South Africa allow me to underline that these negotiations are bilateral. It is therefore up to South Africa to consult its SACU and SADC partners. All these countries are ACP States. They are informed of the state of play in the negotiations by the Commission. If these countries wish to make their positions known and express their concerns to the EU they can do so through the appropriate consultation mechanisms of the Lomé Convention. The Community intends of course to comply fully with this provision.

We are fully aware that South Africa considers the expansion of regional cooperation with the ACP in general to be a matter of priority and I can assure you that due account will be taken of any serious consequences the outcome of the negotiations with South Africa may have for countries in the Southern African region.

Concerning the concrete elements of the question, the Commission has not come forward with any proposals in this respect and I am therefore not in a position to react to them.

Question No 25 by Charlotte Cederschiöld (H−0671/98)

Subject: Sharing of confiscated assets resulting from criminal activity

In its proposal for a legal act (6490/98‐98/909(CNS)) on arrangements for cooperation between Member States in respect of the confiscation of instrumentalities and the proceeds from crime, the Council has made it easier for Member States to work together on matters concerning seizures of such assets. The resolution on an action plan to combat organized crime adopted by Parliament on 20 November 1997 (A4‐0333/97), calls, in relation to Recommendation 26, for consideration to be given to the sharing of illegally acquired assets. In cases where several Member States have cooperated and it is not possible to share out the assets amongst the Member States, will it be possible to award the assets to those who have suffered as a result of the crimes concerned, i.e. the victims? The Council has so far said nothing about the sharing‐out of jointly confiscated assets.

Is the Presidency planning to address this issue during the next six months?

Answer

1. The UK presidency began work on implementing Recommendation 26 of the action plan to combat organized crime during the first half of 1998. A review of the situation in the member States concerning the sharing‐out of assets has shown that most Member States are not in possession of specific legal provisions for the division of assets at international level. However, several Member States would be in a position to share out assets on the basis of administrative law or other specific regulations. The position of the victims of such crimes in relation to the sharing‐out of assets has not been dealt with specifically by the Council.

2. The Council, and in particular the multidisciplinary group on “organized crime’, will submit proposals of a more concrete nature in order to stimulate the debate on the sharing‐out of assets on the basis of the preparatory work which was carried out under the UK presidency. In this respect the multidisciplinary group, in accordance with the Council report on organised crime which was submitted to the European Council in Cardiff, will take into consideration the position of the European Parliament on the action plan of the high‐ranking group for the control of organized crime and will focus particularly on Parliament"s proposals in respect of the victims of organised crime.

Question No 26 by María Izquierdo Rojo (H−0674/98)

Subject: Need for effective policies to prevent the deaths of Moroccan immigrants in makeshift rafts

In view of the appalling news of seven more deaths in addition to the previous deaths of large numbers of illegal immigrants in makeshift rafts in the Straits of Gibraltar, the fact that the EU is not making every endeavour to put an end to this waste of human life as a matter of urgency and the fact there is a new government in the Kingdom of Morocco, what joint actions – campaigns, measures or policies – will be adopted in the immediate future?

Answer

The Council shares the concerns of the honourable Member in respect of the tragic deaths of the seven young Moroccans.

The Council is confident about the situation, in view of the willingness of the new government of the Kingdom of Morocco to address the issues of human rights and democracy and to pursue the process of economic reform. This should make possible greater cooperation, particularly in respect of the urgent need to tackle the problem of unemployment and to improve the economic well‐being of the citizens of Morocco.

The Association Agreement with Morocco is expected to come into effect in the very near future. The Union continues to be committed to supporting Morocco and other countries in that region with a view to improving living conditions, raising the employment rate and reducing the development differential in the Euro‐Mediterranean area. On this basis the Union intends to continue to work closely with Morocco, both as part of the Barcelona process and also on a bilateral level, that is to say under the MEDA programme.

Question No 27 by David Morris (H−0685/98)

Subject: Religious persecution in Saudi Arabia

Non‐Muslim religious worship is banned in Saudi Arabia and there are no public places of worship for non‐Muslims in that country. It is feared that the latest arrests of Christians in Saudi Arabia may result in lengthy prison sentences or even death. Indeed, in March 1997, two Filipino Christians were beheaded by the sword in Riyadh.

In view of the recent spate of detentions, would the Council raise this issue at the next meeting of the Joint/GCC Co‐operation Council, and what other steps would the Council take to secure guarantees from the Saudi authorities regarding the safety of Christians living on their land?

Answer

The EU and the GCC conduct a regular dialogue, both in the framework of the EU‐GCC Joint Councils and Ministerial meetings and at senior officials level. The dialogue, always friendly, has reached a stage of maturity which allows each side to raise any issue, such as human rights.

The EU‐GCC dialogue is multilateral and would not be the ideal forum for raising issues concerning one participant only. The EU side does however engage its GCC counterparts in increasingly open exchanges on fundamental human rights issues.

All EU Member States have co‐sponsored a resolution at the UN Commission on Human Rights on the implementation of the Declaration on the Elimination of all Forms of Intolerance and Discrimination Based on Religion and Belief. This resolution supports the extension of the mandate of the special rapporteur on this issue.

Question No 28 by Robin Teverson (H−0686/98)

Subject: Twelve‐mile fishing limits

Council Regulation EEC 3760/92(1) allowing Member States to maintain restrictions on access to waters under their sovereignty or jurisdiction within a maximum limit of 12 nautical miles is due to expire on 31 December 2002.

Will the Council undertake to ensure that before 31 December 2002 the provisions of this derogation are renewed?

Answer

As the Council pointed out in its reply to Oral Question No H−0569/98 put down by Miss McIntosh on the same subject, the Commission's preparatory work on the review of Regulation No 3760/92 is underway. The Council was given an oral report on the state of play at its meeting on 8 June. However, it is not for the Council to prejudge at this stage any proposals which the Commission may consider appropriate to submit in the context of that review. The Council has, of course, noted Parliament's view, expressed in its Resolution of November last year, that the 12‐mile limit should continue to be for the exclusive use and management of the coastal Member State concerned.

Question No 29 by Inger Schörling (H−0688/98)

Subject: Fermented herring

From 1 July 1998, fermented herring will be covered by the same rules that apply to other fish products in the EU, which means that it may not be kept in old wooden barrels, as has been done since the 16th century, if it is to be sold in food shops, nor may it be handled on premises with wooden floors, such as old boathouses. These rules will affect a one thousand year old industry and tradition in Sweden, making the situation particularly difficult for small local producers. The EU talks of subsidiarity and not interfering in details but does the exact opposite.

Does the Council believe that such detailed regulation is consistent with subsidiarity? If not, does the Council intend to block the directive on fermented herring?

Question No 30 by Ulf Holm (H−0690/98)

Subject: Fermented herring

Under a new EU law which enters into force on 1 July 1998, the same rules will apply to fermented herring as to other fish products in the EU. Traditional fermented herring has been produced in the same way for hundreds of years but now the EU has decided to stick its nose in. The new rules threaten this traditional Swedish herring dish in two main respects: the wooden tubs which have always been used to ferment the herring must be replaced by plastic containers and the premises on which the herring is produced must have a concrete floor. Traditionally, fermented herring is produced in small wooden sheds by small producers as a hobby and the special wooden tubs they use help give the herring its particular flavour, which is now threatened by the EU rules.

The EU's subsidiarity principle is designed to prevent the EU from interfering in detailed regulation. Does the Council really believe that these rules, which threaten to wipe out traditional Swedish fermented herring, are consistent with the EU's subsidiarity principle? Is the Council prepared to amend this directive so that it does not apply to fermented herring?

Joint Answer

The hygiene requirements for the production and marketing of fishery products are laid down in Directive 91/493/EEC.

1. In Chapter III of the Annex to that directive, which lays down general conditions for establishment on land (processing) factories, paragraph 2(a) defines that the named factory premises “shall afford at least the following facilities, in areas where products are handled, prepared and processed:

a)waterproof flooring which is easy to clean and disinfect and laid down in such a way as to facilitate the drainage of the water or provided with equipment to remove water.’

b)There is therefore no special requirement for cement floors. It is up to the relevant authorities in each sovereign state as to how to define the types of floor capable of meeting the hygiene objectives laid down in the directive.

2. The Annex to that directive, namely Chapter IV(6)(c) and Section VI(2) respectively, rules as follows:

’6. Salting

c) Any container used for salting or brining must be constructed in such a way as to preclude contamination during the salting or brining process.’

’2. Packaging materials and products liable to enter into contact with fishery products must comply with all the rules of hygiene, and in particular:

‐ they must not be such as to impair the organoleptic characteristics of the fishery products;

‐ they must not be capable of transmitting to the fishery products substances harmful to human health;

‐ they must be strong enough to protect the fishery products adequately. ‚

These exceptional provisions therefore do not specifically require the use of plastic containers.

The Council certainly has no intention of damaging the traditional Swedish processing industry, provided that the preparation of the products concerned complies with the food hygiene regulations.

The requirements which have been cited also allow the Swedish authorities sufficient scope for interpretation when it comes to the application of the regulations. In the Council"s opinion the principle of subsidiarity has therefore been observed.

Question No 31 by Mark Killilea (H−0692/98)

Subject: Undeclared work

A recent report prepared by the European Commission's Social Affairs Directorate indicates that undeclared work, or work undertaken in the 'black economy' currently represents between 7 and 16 % of European Union GDP.

Given the undoubted impact of undeclared work on the economy of Member States in terms of its effect on competitiveness and on social security systems, etc., and in the context of the European Employment Strategy, can the Council given details of how it intends to pursue a common policy for all the Member States which will tackle this problem?

Answer

The Council has recently been studying a Commission communication on undeclared employment. The Commission has drawn attention to the fact that this communication is based on investigations and reports which were published in connection with the White Paper on Growth, Competitiveness and Employment.

The Council will give every consideration to this communication insofar as it is designed to set in motion a debate as part of the preliminary work needed for establishing the employment‐policy guidelines for 1999.

However, the Commission is not planning to introduce any measures at European Union level before a thorough debate has been held on this subject, something which could be done when drafting the joint report on employment in 1998.

Question No 32 by Gerhard Hager (H−0695/98)

Subject: EU visa policy

EU visa policy is being criticized in some applicant countries. However, the President‐in‐Office of the Justice and Home Affairs Council has stressed that the accession negotiations cannot be brought to a successful conclusion unless the applicant countries take over the body of EU law relating to visa policy.

Does the Council representative share that view? According to his estimation, within what time‐frame could the applicant countries take over this law? Are obligations to that effect being laid down at this stage under the pre‐accession strategies?

Also as far as visa policy is concerned, how does the Council propose to resolve the problem of ethnic Hungarians in Romania?

Answer

As Mrs Quin declared in her address to the Committee on Civil Liberties and Internal Affairs on 30 June 1998, the adoption of the ‚acquis communautaire" by those countries wishing to accede to the Union constitutes the touchstone of the accession negotiations.

This naturally applies to all other areas, including visa policy.

The Council of the European Union for its part is doing everything in its power to support the new applicant countries in reconciling their legislation with the ‚acquis communautaire", particularly in respect of the Third Pillar, as witnessed by the following:

1. During the last half‐year the Council, working closely with the Commission, has completed its work on the definition of the ‚acquis" and has prepared a formal communication on this subject for the applicant countries.

As far as asylum and immigration in particular are concerned, this communication was issued last year under the Dutch presidency.

2. In May 1998 the Council adopted a Joint Measure for establishing a mechanism for the joint evaluation of the adoption, application and efficient implementation of the European Union"s ‚acquis" by the applicant countries in the areas of legal and internal affairs. This Joint Measure provides for the appointment of a group of experts from the Member States, whose role is to undertake the preliminary work for this evaluation and to keep it fully up to date.

3. Finally it should be pointed out that in the area of visa policy meetings regularly take place (one during each presidency) with representatives from those countries wishing to accede to the Union.

As Mr Hager well knows, the Council affords the new applicant countries all possible logistical support in respect of the application and efficient conversion of the "acquis communautaire". At the present time, however, it cannot be said how much time will be needed to achieve this objective. But I can assure Mr Hager that both the Community and the applicant countries have announced their intention to implement the necessary adjustments in this area as quickly as possible.

As regards the Hungarian minority in Romania, it should be mentioned that the visas will be included in the travel documents. Where the travel document has been issued by a country which features in the common Union list, the bearer of the document must be in possession of a visa in order to cross the border of an EU Member State.

Question No 33 by Niall Andrews (H−0698/98)

Subject: Preventing drug smuggling into prisons

Is the Council satisfied that enough is being done in the Member States to prevent illegal drugs from being smuggled into jails and is it aware to what extent information on how best to eliminate drug smuggling into jails is being shared among prison authorities in the Member States?

Answer

The maintenance of public order in the prisons of the Member States is a matter which comes under the jurisdiction of the Member States. The prevention of drug smuggling into prisons is an issue which has not been discussed within the Council.

Question No 34 by José Apolinário (H−0702/98)

Subject: East Timor

What is the Council's assessment of the serious incidents that occurred in East Timor during the visit of the Community troika? How does the Presidency‐in‐Office propose to deal with the East Timor question at the political level?

Answer

The regrettable incidents in East Timor, which took place during the visit of the troika heads of mission to Jakarta, are a clear sign of the divisions which exist. Polarization and mistrust seem to be an obstacle to dialogue and reconciliation. This incident, and others which occurred shortly before the arrival of the EU mission, clearly show the urgent need for measures to build‐up mutual trust, including the firm undertaking that the wishes of the people of East Timor will be consulted directly at some future date.

The European Union will continue to press for a just, comprehensive and internationally acceptable solution to the East Timor problem, a solution which fully guarantees the rights of the people of East Timor and is in accordance with the resolutions adopted by the General Assembly of the UN and the principles laid down in the UN Charter. The efforts which are currently being made under the auspices of the UN General Secretary are fully supported by the EU. The Union will also press for the release of all political prisoners in East Timor, including Xanana Gusmãos. Only when the East‐Timorese people are able to participate in this process, and when the Indonesian Government begins to respect human rights, basic freedoms and internationally recognized principles, will it be possible to find a just solution to this problem.

Question No 35 by Jonas Sjöstedt (H−0703/98)

Subject: Monitoring of telecommunications

The Council has adopted a resolution on the monitoring of telecommunications. Similar rules exist in the USA. Are American and European authorities currently cooperating in this area? If so, what does their cooperation entail?

Answer

1. As far as the legitimate monitoring of telecommunications is concerned, and in particular the monitoring requirements of the criminal prosecution services, the Council adopted a resolution in 1995 which has been published in the Official Journal. The question of monitoring telecommunications is currently being discussed as part of the deliberations on a new agreement on assistance in criminal matters to be drawn up between Member States. The European Parliament stated its position to the draft text in April 1998. The draft is restricted to cooperation between the Member States of the European Union and does not cover cooperation with the United States.

2. The Council has not been involved in proposals aimed at establishing cooperation between the United States and the Member States.

Question No 36 by Jan Bertens (H−0705/98)

Subject: Code of conduct for the arms trade

The code of conduct for the arms trade approved last week by the European Council, leaves many things unclear and fails to set the promised 'high common standards'.

Does the Austrian Presidency regard it as its task to complete and put the finishing touches to the code of conduct? When will the first annual report be issued, what agreements have been made on the content of such an annual report and when will the common list be drawn up?

What role will the European Parliament have in connection with this code? Can the President of the Council agree to the publication of a consolidated version of the annual report followed by a debate in the European Parliament?

What does the Council President propose to do about the Action Programme on the illegal traffic in small arms, the brokering and establishment of an effective system for end‐use controls? Does the Council President see any opportunities for the multilateralization of consultation mechanisms in the case of undercutting, as called for by the European Parliament?

Answer

The Code of conduct for the arms trade was approved on 8 June 1998 in order firstly to set high common standards, which are to be regarded as minimum standards for administrative purposes and for the restraint which should be exercised by all Member States when exporting conventional armaments, and secondly to intensify the exchange of relevant information with the aim of achieving greater transparency.

The arms export policy and hence the implementation of the Code continue to be the responsibility of the Member States and of their export licensing authorities. Mr Bertens will know that the Code does not affect the right of Member States to pursue a more restrictive policy at national level.

As the questioner has already said, the Council must now address two key issues when debating the implementation of the Code.

Firstly, the Council must seek to adopt at the earliest possibly opportunity a common list of military equipment. The relevant working group has already started on this task. It should be pointed out that the Code is to be applied on the basis of national control lists until such time as the common list can be adopted.

Secondly, the Council has to draw up in detail the procedure for the submission of reports, as provided for in the Code. A consolidated report, based on contributions from the Member States, will be submitted to the Council on an annual basis and the Council will then decide on any subsequent actions which have to be taken.

Under the terms of the Code, Member States are obliged to do everything in their power to encourage other arms‐exporting States to adopt the principles and criteria of the Code of conduct.

The European Union has already called upon the associated countries of central and eastern Europe, the associated State of Cyprus and those EFTA nations which belong to the EEA to adopt the principles and criteria of the Code.

The presidency and a number of Member States, acting through bilateral talks, have also taken steps to present the Code to various third countries around the world. Information has also been passed on to those groups of States which are involved in relevant export‐control arrangements. Many countries have shown a great deal of interest in the EU initiative and further contacts are planned in this area.

Question No 37 by Antonios Trakatellis (H−0707/98)

Subject: Environmental pollution in the European Union caused by the FYROM and other third countries

Further to the Commission's answer to my Question P−1655/98 that it has been aware for many years that the River Axios is being polluted by industrial plants in the region of Veles in the FYROM and that the FYROM has not become a contracting party to the UN convention on the protection and use of cross‐border watercourses and international lakes or to the Ramsar Convention, while environmental issues have become a European Union priority, will the Council say:

Why did the cooperation agreement with the FYROM enter into force on 1 January 1998 without any previous measures and commitments by the FYROM to protect the environment, and notably to avoid cross‐border pollution? What measures does it intend to take to put an end to pollution by the FYROM? How will it ensure in future that this pollution of Greek territory, which forms part of the EU, ceases, as it constitutes an environmental crime committed by third countries with which the EU has established relations and concluded agreements?

Answer

The preamble to the cooperation agreement between the European Community and the former Yugoslavian Republic of Macedonia (FYROM), which came into force on 1 January 1998, states that it is the wish of the Parties to the agreement to establish a permanent basis for cooperation in accordance with their international commitments.

The agreement itself provides that with a view to improving public health, living standards and the environment, the common application of technical know‐how in the field of environmental protection, and the promotion of collaboration on environmental issues, the Community and the former Yugoslavian Republic of Macedonia should engage in an exchange of information on the development of their respective policies, with regard to sustainable development, and should promote the joint implementation of specific measures. The cooperation agreement also provides that the FYROM should strive gradually to bring its legal provisions into line with those of the Community and that the Community should provide appropriate technical support to this effect.

As regards the specific problem of the pollution of the River Axios (Vardar) I can point out to the questioner that new legislation is currently being prepared to establish a regulative framework for Community measures in the area of water policy. The Council is confident that a definitive political agreement can be achieved and that its Common Position can be established once the results of the first reading in the European Parliament are forthcoming. The aim of the proposal is to set up a regulative framework for the protection of rivers and other water courses in order to prevent a worsening of the ecological conditions and of the level of pollution of surface waters and their rehabilitation, with a view to improving the condition of the surface water courses. The proposal also provides for coordination and administration measures for catchment areas and for the drawing up of resource management plans for river drainage basins which will help to achieve these objectives on a progressive basis. Even in the case of international river basins which extend beyond the borders of the Community the Member States should attempt to devise a single resources management plan on the basis of which the problems raised by the questioner can be dealt with in an efficient manner.

It is therefore extremely important that this legislation should be adopted as soon as possible.

Question No 38 by Olivier Dupuis (H−0710/98)

Subject: EU initiatives for the introduction of a universal moratorium on executions

The Council of Ministers is to be congratulated on its decision at the meeting in Luxembourg on 29 June 1998 to launch a major international initiative with a view to the universal abolition of the death penalty. Can the Austrian Presidency specify what initiatives the EU intends to take in the coming weeks and in particular whether it intends to place the moratorium issue on the agenda of the next meeting of the United Nations General Assembly?

Answer

The General Affairs Council at its meeting on 29 June adopted new guidelines for EU policy towards third countries in respect of the death penalty. In the relevant document the EU has set out its objective to be the worldwide abolition of the death penalty. The EU will be calling for a gradual reduction in the use of the death penalty in those countries where it still exists and will give every support to the application of certain minimum standards when the death penalty is being enforced. The EU will intensify its initiatives, including declarations and demarches on the death penalty, in its representation on international bodies and when dealing with other countries. The EU will examine on a case‐by‐case basis whether or not to lodge protests against third countries when it comes to the use of the death penalty.

Recent demarches on the death penalty have been made to the authorities of Trinidad and Tobago in respect of their decision to cancel the First Optional Protocol on the UN International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and additionally to withdraw from the American Convention on Human Rights. The EU has also made demarches in the case of individuals who are awaiting execution.

At this year"s United Nations General Assembly all EU Member States will be supporting the traditional Italian initiative on the death penalty. This standpoint has already been adopted by EU Member States at this year"s meeting of the Human Rights Committee in Gent.

Question No 39 by Richard Howitt (H−0711/98)

Subject: Budget for disability actions

Given the legal uncertainty concerning social action programmes following the recent European Court decision, can the Council confirm that it regards budget lines B3‐4106, cooperation between disability organizations, and B3‐4102, Pilot actions on disability, as both worthwhile and uncontroversial, and will do everything possible to confirm a legal base for 1998? Is the Council committed to ensuring that preparatory actions on disability continue in 1999 so that swift action can be taken towards the setting up of a new multi‐annual Disability Programme?

Answer

The Council has been informed of the recent European Court decision concerning the financing by the Commission of social action programmes.

However, at this stage, the Council has received no Commission proposal aiming at establishing a legal basis for the execution of the budgetary lines referred to by the honourable Member of Parliament.

Under the circumstances, it cannot at present express a view on the budgetary lines in question.

Question No 41 by Christine Oddy (H−0715/98)

Subject: Assassination of Monsignor Juan Gerardi, Auxiliary Bishop of Guatemala

Following the assassination of Monsignor Juan Gerardi, Auxiliary Bishop of Guatemala, what success has the Council of Ministers had in demanding a full and just investigation into the killing? What position has the Council taken in relation to the peace process?

Answer

In its statement of 4 May 1998 the Council condemned the cowardly and despicable murder of Monsignor Gerardi and called on all Guatemalans to remain united in their efforts to bring about the full implementation of the peace agreements.

The European Union called on the Guatemalan Government to take all the necessary steps to ensure the comprehensive investigation of this murder so that its perpetrators can be brought to trial. It also urged the Guatemalan Government to support the work of the Truth Commission and to take all the security precautions needed to ensure the protection of its Members.

Moreover, the EU is closely monitoring the peace process and the situation with regard to respect for human rights in Guatemala in preparation for the second meeting of the advisory group scheduled for the autumn. At that meeting the Guatemalan authorities should come up with answers to the Council's questions.

Question No 42 by Nikolaos Papakyriazis (H−0717/98)

Subject: Desecration of a Greek Orthodox cemetery

On 14 May 1998, my question H−0514/98 concerning the desecration of the Greek Orthodox cemetery of Ayios Eleftherios in Istanbul on 1 April 1998 was put to the Council.

In the ensuing debate and the Council's answer of 17 June, in which this act was condemned, it was stated that the Turkish authorities had been asked to take the necessary measures to bring the perpetrators to justice and that the Council would closely monitor the case.

What measures have been taken precisely and, most importantly, what was the response of the Turkish Government as the responsible authority and what stage has now been reached in this case?

Answer

In response to this new question by Mr Papakyriazis I can only make the same observation as my predecessor at the June session in his answer to a similar question which was also put by the honourable Member, namely that the Council regrets the events which took place at the Greek Orthodox cemetery of the Hagios Eleftherios Church in Istanbul and is very much aware of the fact that the Turkish Government is committed, under the Treaty of Lausanne which was signed in July 1923, to grant full protection to churches, synagogues, cemeteries and other religious establishments belonging to non‐Moslem minorities.

To date nothing new has been added to this declaration.

At its session in Luxembourg on 12 and 13 December 1997 the European Council, in accordance with the views expressed at the meeting of the EU‐Turkish Association Council which was held on 29 April 1997, recalled that the strengthening of relations between Turkey and the European Union also depended on the continuation of political and economic reforms, including the conformation of its standards and practices in the area of human rights to those standards and practices which apply in the European Union.

The situation in respect of democracy and human rights in Turkey continues to be high on the Council"s agenda. The Commission"s report to the Council of March 1998 relating to the development of relations with Turkey since the establishment of the Customs Union concluded that Turkey had made very little progress in the area of human rights and the introduction of democratic reforms. These matters are regularly brought up for discussion with the Turkish authorities. Cooperation in the field of human rights and humanitarian issues is part and parcel of the EU strategy for Turkey.

Question No 43 by Eva Kjer Hansen (H−0719/98)

Subject: Catch‐up facility

Does the Council consider it acceptable for the Commission to have approved a paltry ECU 100 millions under the 'catch‐up facility' in response to the Luxembourg Summit decision on a more equitable apportionment of financial aid to the countries of central and eastern Europe regardless of their time of accession?

How does the Council intend to ensure that the decision taken at the Summit will be complied with, and that an analysis will be conducted into the real needs for financial aid in the various applicant countries?

Answer

1. As the questioner will know, the ‚catch‐up facility" put in place by the Commission is basically a reserve fund set up under the PHARE programme; this facility provides support to Bulgaria, Latvia, Lithuania, Rumania and Slovakia. The PHARE budget for 1998 amounts to ECU 40 millions and the budget for 1999 provides for ECU 60 millions. In 1998 and 1999 the support provided by this facility is made available to the various applicant countries in addition to the national PHARE programmes and respective national PHARE financial framework.

2. It should be borne in mind that the catch‐up facility for 1998 und 1999 is related to the amount which is made available under the current PHARE budget. The future of the catch‐up facility after this period will depend on the new financial plans for the period 2000 to 2006. Should the first applicant countries join the Union during this period, then the available aid for accession will be re‐directed exclusively towards the remaining applicant countries. This means that special attention will continue to be paid to those countries with the greatest need.

3. The European Council which met in Cardiff welcomed the considerable progress which has been made in preparing for enlargement since the Luxembourg Summit. The Council has encouraged the Commission to proceed steadily with the provision of aid under the accession partnership and has again stated that the accession aid should be substantially increased.

2. Questions to the Commission

 

Question No 54 by Glyn Ford (H−0655/98)

Subject: Redundancies at De La Rue printing company

On 2 June De La Rue, a multinational printing company, announced 375 redundancies at its flagship company in Gateshead without informing its European Works Council which is due to meet on 15 and 16 July 1998. Does the Commission not feel that De La Rue has acted in a similar way to Renault in the Vilvoorde case and flagrantly ignored the letter and spirit of European Works Council Directive and the Collective Redundancies Directive?

Does this action not demonstrate that the European Works Councils and Collective Redundancies Directives are not sufficient to ensure meaningful and timely information and consultation of employees, and does the Commission therefore agree that legislation to ensure this in all companies within Europe, regardless of whether or not they fall under the provisions of the European Works Council Directive is urgently needed and should be introduced immediately at all companies within Europe?

Question No 57 by Gary Titley (H−0677/98)

Subject: Consultation of the workforce over redundancy decisions

What conclusions has the Commission drawn from the decision by Renault to announce large‐scale redundancies at its Vilvoorde site without adequate consultation of its workforce, as to the effectiveness of EU social legislation, particularly in the field of consultation of the workforce in cases of large‐scale redundancies?

Joint Answer

The Collective Redundancies Directive requires that where an employer is contemplating collective redundancies, consultations with the workers' representative must be undertaken in good time with a view to reaching an agreement.

In relation to Mr Ford's question first, it is not clear from the information provided whether any consultations with the workers' representatives took place before the announcement of the redundancies. If that is not the case, then it would seem that the essential provisions of the Directive have not been respected.

Furthermore, if the decisions taken by the management falls under the scope of the European Works Councils Directive, and under the scope of the agreement concluded on the basis of Article 13 of the Directive, then the relevant procedures for informing and consulting the European Works Council should have been followed.

In relation to both Directives, it is up to the Member States concerned, in the first instance, to examine whether these rules were respected.

As regards Mr Titley's question, the Commission believes that the outcome of the judicial proceedings brought against Renault management, both in France and Belgium, vindicates workers' legitimate demands, and clarifies the legal obligations imposed upon management by the existing Community Directives on Collective Redundancies and European Works Councils.

Nevertheless, this judicial redress does not hide the fact that existing Community and national rules on information and consultation of workers need, to some extent, to be complemented and reinforced. The aim would be to ensure the dissuasive effect of these regulations, while focusing on a positive dialogue to avoid, where possible, the negative effects of corporate restructuring.

This subject is also the remit of the High Level Expert Group on the Economic and Social Impact of Industrial Change. This group has already made a useful contribution in its Interim Report presented some weeks ago, and their final conclusions are expected later this year, in time for them to be addressed by the Vienna European Council.

In reply to the theme which is common to both the questions, the Commission considers that the practice of information and consultation of workers constitutes not only a right for workers faced with the prospect of job losses but is also a pre‐condition for the success of the processes of adaptation and modernisation of European industry.

The Commission therefore believes that there is a need for further legislative action to supplement and complete, within a comprehensive Community framework, the existing national and Community provisions on information and consultation of employees.

This is why the Commission initiated the consultation process of social partners on a European framework for information and consultation. Unfortunately, the social partners were not in a position to indicate that they would engage in negotiations, as a result of a decision by one of the partners not to proceed.

The Commission has therefore prepared a draft directive on employee information and consultation, and that text is now ready. However, there have been recent indications that a social partner negotiation may still be possible, and the honourable Member will be aware that a negotiation has always been the Commission's preferred solution on this matter.

Therefore, the Commission has refrained from putting forward its proposal while rapid soundings are taken on whether a social partner negotiation is a real and immediate possibility.

Question No 55 by Konstantinos Hatzidakis (H−0666/98)

Subject: Funding of Ministry of Education programmes in Greece

The Ministry of Education programmes in Greece which are funded mainly by the European Social Fund are known to be poorly implemented and to have a low take‐up rate. In view of this situation the Ministry of Education is seeking funding for new projects and actions which it considers could function better, such as the Uniform Secondary School (Lycée) project, the university study choice programmes and teacher training programmes. Will the Commission say whether the Greek Ministry of Education has stated exactly how it envisages the institution of the Uniform Secondary School, whether teacher training will be genuine and not just consist in information about scheduled changes and whether it considers that the university study choice programmes will contribute to combating unemployment in Greece, for example?

Answer

The Commission and the Greek authorities are at present discussing the mid‐term review of the ESF.

The operational programme ‚Education and Initial Training’ is the largest programme for human resources in Greece. Its current absorption rate is alarmingly low. The Commission has therefore proposed a scaling down of the operations supported by this programme.

Against this background, the Greek authorities have proposed that more resources be devoted to the Integrated Lyceum and to some new tertiary education measures.

The Commission has been and is supportive of the reforms that the Ministry of Education wants to introduce, and considers that it has received sufficient information on the Integrated Lyceum, the training of teachers and the tertiary education open access courses. The Commission hopes to be able to agree to the co‐financing of these policy areas from the ESF, once the issues raised in the mid‐term review have been resolved with the Greek authorities.

Question No 56 by Hugh McMahon (H−0676/98)

Subject: Denial of unemployment benefit

Is the Commission aware that numerous EU citizens, former employees of the University of Verona, are being denied unemployment benefit as a result of the University of Verona's refusal to complete the necessary social security forms, for reasons known only to itself?

Would the Commission agree that the University's refusal to fulfill its legal responsibilities represents a breach of law and will the Commission give its assurance that it will intercede immediately to ensure that the fundamental social rights of these citizens are ensured?

Answer

The Commission has in fact been informed by representatives of the former employees of alleged practices by the University of Verona which result in the denial of unemployment benefits. If these allegations were proven to be accurate, the Commission would deplore the attitude of the University, which should be more constructive after a decade long conflict with the language lecturers concerned.

However, from a legal point of view, the Commission understands that this issue would be a matter of exclusive Italian competence. If the University is in breach of Italian law, which requires former employers to fill out certain forms so that their employees can obtain unemployment benefits, it is for Italian courts to decide on the legal consequences of a breach of such an obligation by the employer.

Question No 62 by Marianne Eriksson (H−0650/98)

Subject: Surströmming (fermented Baltic herring)

Long articles have recently appeared in a number of Swedish daily newspapers about an EU ban on the traditional Swedish method of producing surströmming (fermented Baltic herring), the reason for the ban supposedly being that Baltic herring must not be kept in wooden casks.
