Is it really possible that the EU thinks it has time enough and good reason to concern itself with a matter such as the production of surströmming?

If so, is it also planning to prohibit traditional methods of producing whisky, which is of course also kept in wooden casks?

Question No 63 by Hadar Cars (H−0673/98)

Subject: Ban on wooden floors and wooden containers in the preparation of 'surströmming' (fermented Baltic herring)

According to the Swedish Food Administration, Swedish producers of surströmming will have to adapt their premises to the EC Directive laying down the health conditions for the production and placing on the market of fishery products (91/493/EEC)(2) , which states that wooden floors and wooden containers may no longer be permitted in the process. Small‐scale 'surströmming' production is usually conducted in fishermen's sheds, to which wooden floors and wooden containers are natural concomitants. Many people believe that the wooden containers used enhance the flavour of 'surströmming' and that this is an important part of the process.

Many small producers in Norrland are threatened with closure on account of this directive. This constitutes a threat to 'surströmming' as a Swedish delicacy.

As 'surströmming' is produced on a small scale, by self‐employed persons and for the national market, in my view its producers should be exempted from the provisions.

Is the Commission prepared to exempt undertakings in Norrland from the provisions in Directive 91/493/EEC banning the use of wooden floors and wooden containers?

Question No 64 by Inger Schörling (H−0689/98)

Subject: Fermented herring

From 1 July 1998, fermented herring will be covered by the same rules that apply to other fish products in the EU, which means that it may not be kept in old wooden barrels, as has been done since the 16th century, if it is to be sold in food shops, nor may it be handled on premises with wooden floors, such as old boathouses. These rules will affect a one thousand year old industry and tradition in Sweden, making the situation particularly difficult for small local producers. The EU talks of subsidiarity and not interfering in details but does the exact opposite. Does the Commission believe that such detailed regulation is consistent with subsidiarity? If not, does the Commission intend to block the directive on fermented herring?

Question No 65 by Ulf Holm (H−0691/98)

Subject: Fermented herring

Under a new EU law which enters into force on 1 July 1998, the same rules will apply to fermented herring as to other fish products in the EU. Traditional fermented herring has been produced in the same way for hundreds of years but now the EU has decided to stick its nose in. The new rules threaten this traditional Swedish herring dish in two main respects: the wooden tubs which have always been used to ferment the herring must be replaced by plastic containers and the premises on which the herring is produced must have a concrete floor. Traditionally, fermented herring is produced in small wooden sheds by small producers as a hobby and the special wooden tubs they use help give the herring its particular flavour, which is now threatened by the EU rules.

The EU's subsidiarity principle is designed to prevent the EU from interfering in detailed regulation. Does the Commission really believe that these rules, which threaten to wipe out traditional Swedish fermented herring, are consistent with the EU's subsidiarity principle? Is the Commission prepared to amend this directive so that it does not apply to fermented herring?

Joint Answer

There is no Community Regulation specifically aimed at the production of fermented herring in wooden casks.

However, the use of wood when it comes into contact with food products (Directive 93/43/EEC on food hygiene) and more specifically when it comes into contact with fishery products (Directive 91/493/EEC) is subject to certain conditions. These conditions, which are in accordance with the recommendations of the codex alimentarius , relate to the cleaning and disinfection of receptacles. Wood is a material which, when porous, becomes impregnated with organic materials such as blood, mucous and faeces, all of which form an excellent environment for the growth of putrefying bacteria.

If the casks used for the fermentation of the herring are used only once, then the only requirement is that they are clean before use. On the other hand, if the casks are reused, it is for the fishermen to demonstrate to the appropriate national authorities, through their programme of compulsory self‐regulation, that the conditions of the directive are being respected, that is, that the casks can be effectively cleaned and disinfected.

Question No 66 by Astrid Thors (H−0657/98)

Subject: Health Claims

The European industry is increasingly asking for EU legislation permitting the use of health claims where they are justified by established scientific evidence. There is a clear danger that non‐European competitors are getting a competitive advantage on the world market by using health claims. Such scientifically backed evidence would obviously be of great value also to consumers when they make their choices.

According to my information DG XXIV has sent out a questionnaire to Member States asking to what extent they would be favourable to new legislation regulating health claims. The answers have, again according to my information, reflected support.

When is the Commission going to propose new legislation regulating health claims?

Answer

The issue of health claims was considered within the framework of the Green Paper on food legislation adopted by the Commission in April 1997. In its comments on the Green Paper, the industry naturally expressed its desire to see Community regulations with regard to the amending of labelling to enable the use of health claims. The issue was also tackled in a Green Paper on marketing communications in the internal market. In the Commission"s communication on follow up to this Green Paper, the issue of claims and of misleading advertising figure amongst the priority areas to be submitted to the group of experts on marketing communications, a group set up by the Commission and consisting of representatives of Member States.

The European Parliament has also expressed an opinion on this subject. In its opinion on the Green Paper on food legislation, it asked the Commission to make proposals aimed at authorizing information regarding reductions in risks of illness, on condition that this information is based on sufficiently recognized scientific evidence which has been confirmed by an independent Community body. In its opinion on the Green Paper on marketing communications, Parliament asked the Commission to pay particular attention to restrictions in marketing communications appearing on packaging.

Given the sensitive nature of this issue, which is linked to the principle of consumer transparency, the Commission is currently undertaking an in‐depth study of the issue.

The Commission can confirm that a questionnaire has indeed been sent to Member States, in order to gather detailed information on existing national legislation concerning health claims, nutritional claims and environmental claims and to obtain their opinion on a possible Commission proposal. Nevertheless, the Commission has to date only received replies from a small number of Member States.

The Commission will draw the relevant conclusions based on all the information available.

Question No 67 by Ulla Sandbæk (H−0696/98)

Subject: Integration of gender issues on ECHO's work

Bearing in mind the 'gender issues in development cooperation' considered at the Council's meeting on 18 May 1998, can the Commission report on ECHO's advances in the process of integrating gender in policy papers, annual reports, training of personnel and in practical field work.

I have not been able to see progress in this part of ECHO's work, apart from the campaign for women in Kabul. This campaign is of course important, but we need a general gender policy in all ECHO's work to ensure the implementation of the Beijing and Council conclusions.

In ECHO's working document 'ECHO strategy 1997' I have not been able to find a strategy concerning gender, just a reference to a 'better integration of gender and environment in practical work'. In the paper 'Guidelines for humanitarian action in 1998' ECHO only mentions gender in the context of the campaign for women in Afghanistan.

All in all ECHO has been surprisingly silent concerning input for the Council resolutions as well as conclusions about gender. In view of the above, how long must we wait to see how ECHO will address the very important question of gender in development cooperation?

Answer

Gender is not an easy issue to tackle in emergency situations. The gender patterns in development cooperation cannot be applied directly to Humanitarian Aid where urgent needs often take priority. Nevertheless, even in emergencies it is clear that consciously or unconsciously, one always takes decisions with a bearing on gender. It makes a big difference whether aid is provided to women, children, men, elderly etc. The type of aid must fit the target group and the correct gender analysis of who should be responsible for administration and distribution of aid is equally essential. Hence, gender is not a quality add‐on but should be part of mainstream operational approach.

It is important to note that ECHO is not an implementing agency. The Commission works through its partners, NGOs, the UN agencies and the Red Cross family. Most of these agencies, represented in the Dialogue Group(3) , have declined to have the gender dimension incorporated within the final version of the Framework Partnership Agreement (the main instrument of the Commission cooperation with partners, currently under revision). They argue that the rehabilitation phase and the longterm is more suitable for this analysis.

Nevertheless, the Commission, as a donor, feels it has an obligation to address the issue and emphasize that analysis of the gender situation be included in all proposals for humanitarian assistance where relevant, especially in those programmes which are less subject to time‐constraints.

One cannot say that gender approach is absent. In emergency situations, the Commission pays particular attention to the needs for protection and assistance of women, e.g. programmes focusing on reproductive health as a concrete and essential aspect of the protection of women and child survival (pregnant and breastfeeding women, post‐natal care and safe motherhood/pregnancies, including deliveries). Special attention is given to female‐headed households and water and sanitation programmes, education and training and income generating activities. The Commission tries to introduce a more participatory approach in order to better target the most vulnerable in each situation, be they women in many cases but also men, elderly, children, disabled.

The Commission intends to undertake a gender oriented evaluation of the impact of different types of emergency aid.

The following initiatives contribute to the integration of gender issues in humanitarian activities:

‐ Manual on ‚Introduction to good humanitarian practices’. It is an effort to increase the awareness of the audience with regard to the existence and value of basic principles that should underpin the standards of humanitarian aid. Gender is treated under the chapter of vulnerability and dependency.

‐ Guidelines for applicants for training purposes. Programmes funded by the Commission include the gender perspective.

‐ Short policy paper to field expert. The Commission has recently distributed to all experts in the field a short paper on main gender concerns in emergency operations.

‐ The Commission has placed female experts in countries where the gender discrimination is particularly exacerbated (Afghanistan).

‐ The new version of the ECHO's Evaluation Manual , currently under revision, will include indicators on gender to measure the impact of the operations.

Question No 68 by Jonas Sjöstedt (H−0704/98)

Subject: Satellite surveillance of fishing boats

Fishermen in Sweden, Denmark and elsewhere have criticised the EU's requirement of satellite surveillance of fishing boats as unnecessary. A considerable number of fishermen are refusing to comply with the rules entailed by the system.

Will the Commission listen to the fishermen's criticisms and amend the rules or will it take any other measures to resolve the problems involved?

Answer

The Commission realizes that the introduction of a surveillance system may cause reluctance on the part of some. Nevertheless, everyone is aware that control is the cornerstone of the common fisheries policy.

Everyone has been in a position to notice on many occasions that the implementation of controls remains too limited. In this respect, the implementation of new technologies constitutes a key factor in surmounting the noted shortcomings. This is why, based on a Commission proposal, the Council decided to establish a system of continual location of Community fishing vessels. The Commission is pleased with the Council"s decision, which constitutes an important step in the right direction.

The Commission would particularly like to draw the attention of the honourable Member to the fact that satellite surveillance enables the best guarantee of transparency of control and assures the greatest fairness, whilst significantly reducing the costs generated by other more traditional surveillance systems.

It would remind the honourable Member that at the time, Parliament approved the Commission proposal.

Finally, the Commission would like to inform the honourable Member that it has recently introduced a new proposal for modification of the Regulation on monitoring which, amongst other things, provides for the extension of VMS to third country vessels operating in Community waters.

Question No 69 by Richard Howitt (H−0712/98)

Subject: Humanitarian aid in Chiapas

Recent developments in Chiapas have brought about the displacement of more than 9000 indigenous people forcing them to take refuge in different places under the protection of the Mexican Red Cross and Civilian Peace Camps. However, the army and police have not disarmed the paramilitary groups who continue to terrorize and threaten the local people. Parliament resolutions have called for an identification and disarmament of the paramilitaries, but this has not happened. I visited the area in February this year and witnessed ever‐increasing paramilitary presence and terror in the region. I understand the Commission earmarked funds for NGOs implementing humanitarian action in Chiapas. Has it meanwhile received the approval of the Mexican government to start activities and, in a climate where illegal forces operate with impunity, how could the EU contribute to an improvement of the situation for the local people?

Answer

1. On 6 April 1998, the Commission decided to grant ECU 1 450 000 in humanitarian aid over an eight‐month period with a view to securing minimum living conditions for displaced persons.

2. That aid will be implemented by three European NGOs which have experience in that region:

‐ Médicos del Mundo – Spain

‐ German Red Cross

‐ Spanish Red Cross.

Their work will include medical assistance, food aid, the provision of temporary shelters and water purification.

3. At present, now that they have received authorization from the Mexican Government to carry out their activities in Chiapas, the various NGOs are in the process of fulfilling their tasks (supplying food, medicaments and basic necessities, etc.). Those activities remain unaffected either by the tension in the region or by the constantly increasing numbers of displaced persons.

Question No 71 by Alexandros Alavanos (H−0606/98)

Subject: Payment of third instalment with a view to increasing the share‐capital of Olympic Airways

The third instalment of the increase in the share‐capital of Olympic Airways amounting to Drs. 35 billion provided for under the 1994 OA restructuring plan has still not been paid. Since this sum is considered indispensable if the airline is to survive, given both the financial problems it is facing and the imminence of the summer period with the attendant increase in tourist numbers, will the Commission say whether it will speed up the procedures for approving the third instalment of the increase in the share‐capital so as to enable Olympic Airways to exploit to the maximum the opportunities offered by the summer market?

Answer

To date, the second and third tranche of capital injections (respectively 23 and 12 billion Drachma) as well as the State guarantees (worth 378 billion Drachma) initially authorised in 1994 remain blocked following the reactivation of the State aid procedure by the Commission in 1996.

The Commission will only be in a position to close this procedure and authorise the granting of this aid to Olympic Airways if the following conditions are fulfilled:

First, that it is fully satisfied that the respect by the Greek authorities have respected the commitments given to the Commission under the terms of the decision of 1994 which initially authorised the aid;

Second, that it is fully satisfied that Olympic Airways will return to durable profitability and become viable again. In keeping with the requirements always made in these cases, this should be ensured by the effective implementation of a new and effective comprehensive restructuring programme.

The Commission reopened the State aid procedure for Olympic Airways two years ago. At all stages we have very clearly communicated the problems that prevented an earlier resolution of the case.

Substantial progress has been achieved over recent months. The Commission now hopes that it will shortly be in a position to adopt a final decision.

Question No 72 by Nikitas Kaklamanis (H−0625/98)

Subject: Olympic Airways

Olympic Airways is known to be facing problems following the spectacular failure of the 1994‐1997 rationalization programme.

To the Commission's knowledge, what infringements were committed by the Government and the Olympic Airways administration in implementing the rationalization programme? What is the situation concerning the widely‐publicized action taken by pilots in response to the planned change of ownership? Has the measure been abandoned or is it still continuing?

Have any foreign airlines shown interest in purchasing Olympic Airways and, if so, which? Under what conditions does the Commission intend to authorize state aid for Olympic Airways (by increasing its share capital by DR 35bn and standing surety for a loan of $378m) and when could it do so?

Answer

As the Commission advised in answer to Oral Questions H−468, H−439 and H−442/98 in May, the Commission decided to reopen the State aid procedure relating to Olympic Airways in 1996 and, as a result, the aid measures which had not yet been granted were suspended.

That decision was taken because of the failure of the Greek State to observe various commitments which it had given in order to ensure that the aid was compatible with the rules of the common market. Interference in the management of the company and granting of aid in addition to that specified in the State Aid agreement were significant breaches of the relevant commitments.

The Greek authorities have not informed the Commission about any decision to change the ownership structure of the company. Policies on such matters are, of course, without prejudice to Directive 77/187/EEC(4) on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to the safeguarding of employees' rights in the event of transfers of undertakings, businesses or parts of businesses, within the exclusive competence of the Member State governments under the terms of Article 222 of the EC Treaty.

As the honourable Member will understand, it would not be appropriate for the Commission to speculate about newspaper rumours that other airlines might be interested in purchasing part of Olympic Airway's equity.

To date, the second and third tranche of capital injections – 23 and 12 billion Drachma respectively – as well as the State guarantees (worth 378 billion Drachma) that were initially authorised in 1994 continue to be suspended as they have been since the reopening of the State Aid procedure on the Olympic case in 1996.

The Commission would be able to authorise the granting of State Aid to Olympic Airways if the following conditions were fulfilled:

‐ first, that the Commission is fully satisfied that the Greek authorities are respecting the commitments given under the terms of the Commission decision of 1994 which initially authorised the aid;

‐ second, that the Commission is fully satisfied that Olympic Airways will return to durable profitability and become viable again. As in all other similar cases, this should be ensured by the effective implementation of a new and comprehensive restructuring programme.

Question No 73 by Gisèle Moreau (H−0627/98)

Subject: Training manual for Olympic Airways' cabin crew

Directive 97/C 263/04 lays down the standards of training for cabin crew in civil aviation applicable from April 1998, which Olympic Airways has failed to implement.

Has Olympic Airways' current cabin crew training programme been brought into line with the safety regulations and general rules on work and health for employees in the industry laid down by the above directive and how will the Commission intervene to ensure that this is done as soon as possible and thereby boost the credibility of the airline?

Answer

To date the Council of Ministers has not adopted a directive laying down the standards of training for cabin crew in Civil Aviation. The Commission adopted a proposal(5) on 22 July 1997, for a directive on the safety requirements and attestation of professional competence for cabin crews in Civil Aviation. This proposal has been debated in the European Parliament, the Economic and Social Committee and the Council but as yet has not been adopted as Community law. National provisions currently regulate this issue.

Question No 74 by Honório Novo (H−0628/98)

Subject: Cost of transferring Olympic Airways to Spata

The new Athens airport, Eleftherios Venizelos, is due to start operating in the year 2001 and Olympic Airways is meant to have completed its transfer to the airport by the year 2000.

As Olympic Airways is the only European airline required to relocate, at an estimated cost of some Drs 100 billion, while it is also undergoing a period of restructuring owing to major financial problems, how, in the Commission's view, will the huge cost of relocation be covered and is additional support envisaged to avoid the relocation of the company affecting its efforts to restructure.

Answer

All carriers currently operating services to Hellenikon airport will face moving costs when that airport is opened as the new Spata airport. Those carriers that use Hellenikon as a base for their operations and a hub for their network will obviously face greater costs. Olympic Airways and other Greek carriers are likely to be in such a position.

With regard to Olympic Airways in particular, the company is presently assessing the costs of the move. Preliminary estimates, which have been given to the Commission, are below the figure referred to by the honourable Member in his question.

Under the terms of the Commission decision of 7 October 1994 concerning the aid granted by Greece to Olympic Airways, the Greek State committed itself not to grant to the company any further state aid in any form whatsoever. On this basis, any aid granted to Olympic Airways for its move to Spata would constitute a breach of this commitment and would be likely to bring further into question the compatibility of the state aid which was initially authorised in 1994.

However, financial compensation granted by the State to Olympic Airways for the damages incurred by the loss of facilities at Hellenikon on the basis of Greek law relating to breach of contract would not be considered by the Commission as an aid within the meaning of the European Treaty.

Question No 75 by Jean Querbes (H−0635/98/rev. 1)

Subject: Greek Government and political party debts to Olympic Airways

It is claimed that the use of a Falcon aircraft exclusively for the needs of the Greek Government, the frequent use of Olympic Airways' aircraft and helicopters by Greek ministerial departments and political parties' debts for transporting their candidates during the last elections have created a debt of more than Drs 12 billion to Olympic Airways, disrupting the company's business plan and undermining its credibility. Bearing in mind that the company is undergoing a severe financial crisis and that the Greek Parliament recently passed a new law concerning its restructuring, does the Commission believe it is consistent with Community law for the government and political parties to run up huge debts and for it to be decided that the debts will be paid off interest‐free after a certain number of years, while Olympic Airways borrows at market rates? Is the company free to pursue an independent administrative and commercial policy when the government intervenes to obtain preferential rates and treatment? Will freeing Olympic Airways from arbitrary, government‐imposed costs help it to succeed with its restructuring programme?

Answer

Under the terms of the State aid procedure relating to Olympic Airways, reimbursement of debts owed by the Greek State and various public entities to Olympic Airways is one of the conditions which the Greek State is required to respect in order to secure a positive outcome.

The original 1994 Commission decision relating to this case required – inter alia – the payment of all past State and public entity debts to Olympic Airways. Such payment is progressively taking place and is being closely monitored by the Commission. The Commission hopes that by the end of 1999, all debts will have been repaid. According to the information transmitted by the Greek authorities, under Greek law, the State does not pay interest on its debts to public companies.

The 1994 Commission decision authorising the aid granted to Olympic Airways by the Greek State also made the payment of that aid subject to the fulfilment of other conditions in order to make it compatible with the rules of the Community.

Amongst those conditions was one requiring that the State refrained from any interference in the management of the company, except within the strict limit of its role as shareholder. The State therefore had an obligation not to give to Olympic Airways any preferential treatment which would be contrary to Community law and a further obligation to allow the management of Olympic Airways the freedom to determine its commercial policy as well as its administrative and recruitment policy. In this respect, the control of the Board shall not extend to day to day management and must be limited to the definition of the general objectives of the company, in accordance with common Greek company law.

This condition has been amongst those that have not been respected in the past.

The Commission is currently establishing whether the Greek authorities are respecting this condition and it is not aware of any intervention of the government to allow the company to obtain preferential loan rates.

Full respect for the conditions relating to a State aid decision is an important element in building success for the restructuring programmes like the one in Olympic Airways, since it ensures that the company is commercially motivated and capable of adapting to market changes.

Question No 76 by Angela Sierra González (H−0636/98)

Subject: Olympic Airways management contract

Pursuant to Law 2414 of 25 June 1996, the chairman of Olympic Airways must be appointed for a period of five years, with a well‐defined management contract, and report each year to the Greek Parliament.

Does the management contract provided for by the law and required by the restructuring process approved by the Commission exist? Has Olympic Airways lodged its fifteen‐year corporate development plan with the EU? Are the management programme and the development plan both necessary for the restructuring of Olympic Airways?

Answer

Both the management contract and the strategic development programme relating to Olympic Airways are required by Greek company law. Since it is not the role of the Commission to ensure that the domestic laws of Member States are properly implemented, it has not requested these documents from Olympic Airways.

The five‐year restructuring programme of Olympic Airways, which is intended to enable the company to return to profitability and to secure its viability within a reasonable time frame, has been given by the Greek authorities to the Commission.

Question No 77 by Sérgio Ribeiro (H−0637/98)

Subject: Olympic Airways' corporate regulations and personnel plan

Under the general provisions of the law concerning the restructuring of Olympic Airways agreed with the EU, the company is required, within a short period of time, to draw up a new personnel plan reducing the number of management tiers and submit new corporate regulations setting out the necessary conditions for the modernization of the company, an improvement in industrial relations and an increase in productivity.

Why have these measures not been implemented during the long period that has elapsed since 1994 to the present day and how will the Commission intercede with Olympic Airways to ensure that the new personnel plan and corporate regulations are drawn up and favourable conditions created to enable the new restructuring programme for the airline to succeed?

Answer

The 1994 Greek law implementing the initial restructuring programme of Olympic Airways provided for changes in the working conditions of the staff with the objective of fostering increases in productivity.

It became evident, however, that these measures were not sufficient to secure the viability of the company and the success of the restructuring. In April 1998, therefore, the Greek Parliament adopted a law that imposed new working conditions that were aimed at securing the expected productivity gains and labour cost reductions. On this basis, Olympic Airways has been able to establish a new restructuring plan that has been submitted to the Commission in the framework of the State aid procedure currently under way.

The Commission is currently finalising its assessment of this new restructuring plan and will come to a decision in due course.

Question No 78 by Abdelkader Mohamed Ali (H−0643/98)

Subject: Selection criteria for members of the Board of Directors of Olympic Airways

The Board of Directors of Olympic Airways which is currently undergoing restructuring includes a number of persons whose professional qualifications and training are unrelated to air transport.

Will the Commission say whether it considers that a majority of members of the board of directors of an airline must have some familiarity with the relevant issues if it is to have the requisite expertise, flexibility and decision‐taking competence and the ability to pursue an independent policy? Is this not a precondition for the successful restructuring of OA?

Answer

The Commission considers that the appointment of company Board members is the exclusive competence of the shareholders and their prime responsibility. As the Board is normally not involved in day to day management but in the definition of the general objectives of a company, its members do not necessarily require extensive experience of the particular sector in which the company is operating. However, the Boards of the most successful Community air carriers do typically include experienced senior business people and/or managers of very large companies that are exposed to competition.

Question No 79 by Bernie Malone (H−0611/98)

Subject: Nuclear arms race in South Asia

While deploring the circumstances that have led to a nuclear arms race on the Indian sub‐continent, which threatens to spill over into neighbouring Iran, would the Commission not agree that this race is directing resources away from development and the reduction of poverty to the military industrial complex and would it not agree that the imposition of sanctions in these circumstances amounts to no more than the punishment of the powerless for the sins of the powerful?

Answer

The Commission shares the concerns expressed by the honourable Member of Parliament. Indeed it is the case that more than 90 % of the EC's financial aid allocated to India and Pakistan is focused on poverty alleviation. In the current circumstances cutting of this aid is not desirable. However, both India and Pakistan have to receive a strong signal from the international community that nuclear proliferation is not in their own interest or that of regional stability. The Community has therefore adopted a balanced package of measures.

Question No 80 by Mark Watts (H−0613/98)

Subject: Use of taxpayer's subsidies for duty‐free industry

Now that the Commission has recognized that there will be negative economic impacts from the proposed abolition of intraEU duty‐ and tax‐free in 1999 and has agreed to produce proposals for compensatory measures from EU funds to the regions most affected, how does it justify using taxpayers' money to pay for abolition of an industry which is currently self‐financing and provides employment and economic benefits to regions around Europe?

Answer

At no point in time has the Commission recognised that the Council's decision to abolish intra‐Community duty‐free sales in 1999 will have negative consequences. What the Commission has said on several occasions, notably during the Ecofin meeting on 19 May 1998, is that it is up to the individual Member States concerned to consider if and to what extent specific regional difficulties may occur after the abolition of duty‐free sales. This involves an assessment and evaluation of local or regional effects at national level.

On that basis, Member States may decide, in partnership with the Commission, to take appropriate measures to which they could wish to seek support from the Community. They will need to do so under existing procedures. If the structural impact on a particular region concerned by the abolition of duty‐free sales is sufficiently significant, funding from Structural Funds may be envisaged within the framework of the new regulation proposed by the Commission covering the period 2000‐2006.

It should be noted that some Member States, notably Ireland, Denmark and Sweden, have already conducted national studies on the regional aspect while others are planning to do so in the near future.

During the Ecofin meeting on 19 May 1998, the Commission undertook to prepare a working paper to clarify the instruments available to Member States to address any consequences of the abolition of intra‐EU duty‐free sales on 1 July 1999. This paper which will be available to the European Parliament should facilitate the application by Member States of existing procedures. It does not imply any intention on the part of the Commission to propose any other compensatory measures.

Question No 81 by John Cushnahan (H−0647/98)

Subject: Abolition of duty‐free sales

When, precisely, will the Commission be presenting its working document clarifying the 'instruments available to Member States for addressing the consequences of the abolition of intra‐EU duty‐free sales on 1 July 1999'?

Answer

The Commission did indeed give an undertaking to the Ecofin Council on 19 May 1998 that it would draw up a working document clarifying the 'instruments available to Member States for addressing the consequences of the abolition of intra‐EU duty‐free sales on 1 July 1999'.

The Commission is currently in the process of drawing up that document which it will submit to the Council in the autumn of this year.

The working document will also be forwarded, for information, to Parliament.

Question No 82 by Pat Gallagher (H−0679/98)

Subject: Accompanying measures to the possible abolition of duty‐free sales

The Commission has said that national and EU funds might be used to offset any possible effects of the abolition of intra‐EU duty and tax‐free sales on 30 June 1999.

Given that a number of Member States have already indicated a desire to reduce their contribution to the Community's budget for cohesion and Structural Funds, and the movement towards overall budgetary constraints, could the Commission confirm where the funds for accompanying measures will come from?

Answer

The Commission would like to inform the honourable Member of the European Parliament that, at the request of the Ecofin Council, the Commission is currently preparing a document to clarify the instruments that are available for Member States when addressing specific regional difficulties following the abolition of intra‐Community duty‐free sales on 1 July 1999.

With regard to the question of funds available to Member States at national level and the budgetary constraints Member States may face, the Commission has to underline that, in terms of own expenditure, it is up to the Member States to determine the priorities. However, it has to be emphasized that the abolition of duty‐free sales is expected to generate additional revenues for Member States.

As regards Community Structural Funds, the Commission has put forward a proposal for a new regulation covering the period 2000‐2006. Whenever this proposal is adopted, support from Structural Funds may be used for affected eligible regions, within the programme priorities and for eligible costs. It requires that the structural impact on employment within a particular region concerned by the abolition of duty‐free sales is sufficiently significant.

Question No 83 by David Bowe (H−0617/98)

Subject: Directive 96/29 EURATOM on basic safety standards on ionizing radiation

Can the Commission tell the committee in what ways the Council Directive 96/29(6) EURATOM will improve the standards for protection offered to workers and the general public against the dangers arising from ionizing radiation?

Answer

The Basic Safety Standards for the health protection of the general public and workers against the dangers of ionizing radiation (Directive 96/29/EURATOM) are the latest outcome of continued efforts over 40 years to update the Standards in the light of scientific knowledge and operational experience and to strengthen regulatory control of practices. The Directive on Basic Safety Standards currently in force is 80/836/EURATOM(7) as amended by Directive 84/467/EURATOM(8) . The new Directive, adopted in May 1996, will replace these two Directives and is to be transposed by May 2000.

The dose limit for workers, 50 mSv (milli Sievert) per year in Directive 80/836/EURATOM, has been constrained to 100 mSv in five years. The annual dose limit for members of the public is reduced from 5 mSv to 1 mSv, which is below the average exposure from natural sources.

The scope of the Standards has been widened to include specific provisions for work activities involving natural radiation sources (e.g. radon gas in workplaces). More explicit requirements have been introduced with regard to preparedness for and response to radiological emergencies.

A stricter regime of regulatory control has been established which includes a more coherent approach to possible exemptions from the general requirement of reporting, and a more explicit list of types of practices subject to prior authorisation, including the disposal, recycling or reuse of materials containing radioactive substances. A number of practices are now prohibited which were previously subject to prior authorisation and thus left to the judgement of Member States.

In Directive 80/836/EURATOM1 neither reporting nor prior authorisation are required for activities involving radioactive substances of a concentration of less than 100 Bq g−1 (Becquerel per gram). Now a list of radionuclide‐specific exemption values has been introduced which for the most dangerous radionuclides are a factor 10 to 100 more restrictive. The approach for deriving such values has a more solid scientific basis than the previous single value. It results from this approach that on the other hand for many radionuclides with very low radiotoxicity higher exemption values are introduced, whilst still ensuring that the exempted practice does not contribute to more than 1 % of the annual dose limit for members of the public.

It is worth noting that the exemption values may no longer be applied to radioactive waste. The new Directive introduces the concept of ‚clearance’, to be implemented by national authorities on the same radiological basis as the exemption values, which implies that, in general, clearance levels will be lower than the corresponding exemption values.

This development of the concepts of exemption and clearance thus represents a stricter and more coherent system of regulatory control.

In conclusion, the new Directive provides:

‐ stricter dose limits for members of the public and exposed workers;

‐ a more coherent and stricter system of regulatory control;

‐ a widened scope of application to include natural radiation sources;

‐ more explicit provisions for planning and response in relation to radiological emergencies,

and, as such, ensures improved standards for protection offered to workers and the general public against the dangers arising from ionizing radiation.

Question No 84 by David Martin (H−0621/98)

Subject: Wild‐caught monkeys used in experiments in Belgium

Is the Commission aware that wild‐caught monkeys are regularly used in experiments in Belgium, in possible contravention of Directive 86/609/EEC(9) and can the Commission inform me on the progress of the complaint made by the British Union for the Abolition of Vivisection on this subject (No 97/4932), what investigation it has made in this regard and what action it will be willing to take?

Answer

Further to the complaint to which the honourable Member refers, the Commission has investigated the matter and has come to the conclusion that, in its opinion, Council Directive 86/609/EEC on the protection of animals used for experimental and other scientific purposes only applies to procedures related to production processes which can be qualified as serving ‚scientific purposes’. In other terms, the reference in Article 3(a) to ‚manufacture’ should be interpreted in light of Article 2(d) which requires that the use of the animals fulfils ‚experimental or other scientific purposes’.

Since it appears from the above‐mentioned complaint that the wild‐caught monkeys are basically used as ‚raw material’ for the production of a vaccine and the testing afterwards of its fitness for use (neurovirulence testing), the Commission considers that the Directive does not apply in the present case.

Question No 85 by Antoni Gutiérrez Díaz (H−0622/98)

Subject: Overbooking by airlines

Recently there have been many cases of overbooking affecting passengers who have bought their tickets well in advance.

Does the Commission not consider that measures should be taken to reduce the 10 % margin for overbooking enjoyed by airlines and exempt from this practice passengers who have paid for their tickets at least five days in advance?

Answer

As the honourable Member will know, the airline practice of overbooking is only accepted because air transport users insist on keeping the flexibility that the full fare ticket offers.

Unless passengers gave up such arrangements airlines could not be obliged to refrain from overbooking and neither could they be required to offer special advantages to passengers who have bought their tickets at some specific time in advance. Part of the problems which afflict those passengers can be mitigated by the terms of the denied‐boarding compensation Regulation.

At present, there are no official statistics on overbooking. This situation should, however, be improved once Parliament and the Council adopt the Commission's proposal to amend the Regulation.

Meanwhile, the Commission has been informed by airlines that the percentage margin for overbooking corresponds to the statistical number of no shows. If airlines were to reduce this percentage, they would be operating with more empty seats, and, obviously, passengers would consequently have to pay increased fares.

This airline practice is also supported by consumers and mitigation of the difficulties is, therefore, best achieved through a system for reasonable recompense within the framework of the Regulation on denied‐boarding compensation.

Question No 86 by Ian White (H−0624/98)

Subject: Import duty on finished cotton goods

Would the Commission advise why import duty has been imposed on finished cotton goods from outside of the European Union thereby making it impossible for many European Union textile firms to compete with imports of finished cotton goods with the possibility of loss of employment within the European Union and contravention of the relevant Council Advisory Committee which voted 9 to 5 against renewing import levies?

What does the Commission contend is the legal authority for this alleged decision?

Answer

The Commission in its response has assumed that this question refers to the anti‐dumping proceeding concerning imports of unbleached cotton fabrics originating in the People's Republic of China, India, Indonesia, Pakistan, Egypt and Turkey.

On 7 April 1998 the Commission imposed provisional anti‐dumping duties on imports of unbleached cotton fabrics originating in the above‐mentioned countries. Unbleached cotton fabrics is a raw material which is further processed into finished goods.

The investigation, which was opened on 11 July 1997 showed that dumped imports of the above‐mentioned product were causing material injury to the Community weaving industry. The Community interest aspects of the case were extensively examined and the Commission concluded that no compelling reasons existed on Community interest grounds not to impose anti‐dumping measures. In this respect the Community finishing industry argued that anti‐dumping duties on unbleached fabrics would lead to a switch in imports from unbleached fabrics to finished products which would cause injury to them. The Commission found, however, that this risk is limited given the existence of quotas on the imports of finished fabrics and by the competitive advantages enjoyed by Community finishers in terms of know‐how, design and proximity to its customers.

Since the investigation showed the existence of injurious dumping and no compelling reasons were found on Community interest grounds not to impose anti‐dumping measures, the Commission decided to adopt provisional anti‐dumping measures. Following Article 7 of Council Regulation (EC) No 384/96 governing anti‐dumping proceedings, the above provisional measures were imposed by the Commission after consulting the Anti‐dumping Advisory Committee consisting of representatives of the Member States. Indeed, it is the responsibility of the Commission to impose provisional anti‐dumping measures, after having heard the Advisory Committee, whereas it is the Council which is called upon to impose definitive anti‐dumping measures at the final stage of the proceeding, if any.

Question No 87 by Esko Seppänen (H−0626/98)

Subject: Salaries at the European Central Bank

The Executive Board of the European Central Bank has been appointed without any prior decision having been taken on the level of their salaries, their pensions or other social benefits. The European Union's pay scales are made public. The same principle should be observed in the European Central Bank.

How are the salaries, pensions and social benefits of the ECB's executives set, what decision has been taken about them with regard to the appointed members of the board, and what is the role of the Ecofin or the Euro‐X Council in this decision?

Answer

According to the Statute of the European System of Central Banks (ESCB) and the European Central Bank (ECB), which is laid down in a Protocol annexed to the Treaty, the terms and conditions of employment of the members of the Executive Board, in particular their salaries, pensions and other social security benefits shall be the subject of contracts with the ECB. The terms and conditions shall be fixed by the Governing Council of the ECB on a proposal from a Committee comprising three members appointed by the Governing Council and three members appointed by the Council. The members of the Executive Board do not have the right to vote in the respective decisions.

The Statute of ESCB and the ECB also provides that the conditions of employment of the staff of the ECB, including salaries, pensions and other benefits are laid down by the Governing Council of the ECB, on a proposal from the Executive Board. The Council has no formal role to play in this procedure.

Question No 88 by Nuala Ahern (H−0639/98)

Subject: Safety assessments at Dounreay and Sellafield into on site radioactive waste management problems at both sites

Did the UK nuclear safety authorities provide the Commission with the safety assessments carried out by the Nuclear Installation Inspectorate at Dounreay and the UK Atomic Energy Authority at Sellafield into on site radioactive waste management problems at both sites which were revealed to the media on June 15 and 17 respectively?

Answer

Member States are not required to communicate to the Commission reports such as those referred to in the media on June 15 and 17 respectively. Indeed there is no Community legislation specific to the matters these reports address.

Nevertheless, in the general context of the application of the Community Basic Safety Standards for the health protection of the general public and workers against the dangers of ionizing radiation, it is the Commission's practice to seek further information when reports such as those in question come to its attention.

The information thus received in the present case does not indicate a failure by the UK competent authorities to seek to ensure compliance with the Community Basic Safety Standards.

Question No 89 by Caroline Jackson (H−0649/98)

Subject: Brandy butter

The British press reported on 21 June that one effect of EC legislation on spreadable fats is that British style 'brandy butter' could not retain this name if is contains less than 34 per cent butter, despite the fact that any attempt to produce the recipe with more than 34 per cent butter results in a greasy mess.

Can the Commission confirm or deny the truth of this story?

If the story is in fact true, can the Commission suggest how brandy butter can continue to be produced, bearing in mind that this shelf‐stable product is generally produced by SMEs?

Answer

According to Commission Regulation (EC) No 577/97, Article 3, the milkfat content of a composite product containing butter has to be at least 75 %, if the product is to be marketed under the designation ‚butter’. There are exceptions for products which have traditionally been made using a lower amount of butter. Among these products listed in the annex to Regulation 577/97, brandy butter is mentioned. The milkfat content of brandy butter and similar products containing other alcoholic beverages has to be at least 34 %. This figure takes a request made by the UK Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food into consideration. The Commission is not aware of any problem caused by the requirement to respect the minimum milkfat content specified above, which corresponds according to its information to the milkfat content of traditional brandy butter.

Question No 90 by Florus Wijsenbeek (H−0652/98)

Subject: Overtaking ban on motorways

As experience with bans on overtaking by lorries on motorways in the Netherlands has been positive, it is likely that such bans would also have positive effects in other Member States if introduced there.

Did the Commission request that this subject be placed on the agenda for the Transport Council of 18 June 1998?

If not, does it intend to request its inclusion on the agenda for the next Transport Council?

Answer

The ban on overtaking by lorries on motorways in the Netherlands has been shown to be effective in reducing accidents there. As the honourable Member will know, however, the results of such initiatives depend upon the level of and variations in motorway traffic density and speed, the mix of vehicle types in the traffic flow, the carriageway and slip road layout of the motorway network and weather conditions. Decisions about whether or not to apply overtaking bans on lorries travelling on motorways are, consequently, most appropriately taken by Member State governments because they are in the best position to assess their national traffic conditions and the effectiveness of overtaking bans.

The Commission is naturally prepared to promote discussion of such initiatives. However, since action at Community level does not seem warranted, the Transport Council is unlikely to be the best setting for such exchanges.

Question No 91 by Maj Theorin (H−0660/98)

Subject: The situation in Afghanistan

The ruling Taliban in Afghanistan has in the past week imposed further restrictions on the rights of women and girls. The few schools in the capital at which girls could still receive an education have now been closed, and even tougher rules have been introduced for women who need medical treatment, as a result of which certain groups of women are now completely excluded from all forms of health care.

How does the Commission view developments in Afghanistan? What steps will it take to uphold the rights of women and girls there?

Answer

The Commission shares the concern of the honourable Member regarding Afghanistan. It follows closely the development of the situation in Afghanistan, and in particular the situation of women there.

Two missions were carried out recently by the EU to urge the Taliban to facilitate the implementation of aid provided by the international community and respect the right to equal access of men and women to health and education. The first, a Community donor mission took place in April 1998 and the second, an EU Troika mission in June 1998.

Regarding the present worsening of the attitude of the Taliban towards women's education and the NGO community carrying out essential aid work in Afghanistan, UN Under Secretary General for Humanitarian Affairs Sergio Vieira de Mello has asked his representative on the ground to initiate a new démarche to discuss these serious issues with the Taliban. Further steps to be taken will depend on the outcome of these talks.

In view of the recent developments the Commission believes that the efficiency and equity of humanitarian relief operations are put increasingly under stress. Should the situation not improve in the coming weeks, a serious rethinking of the way Community aid is administered on the ground may be necessary.

Question No 92 by Philippe Monfils (H−0661/98/rev. 1)

Subject: UEFA required to comply with Treaty rules

UEFA has recently ruled that no more than one football club controlled by the same firm may participate in the same European competition. This rule could already be applied to several clubs next season. This would involve their elimination from the competitions in question even though in sporting terms they have qualified. To another Member's written question on this subject the Commission replied that it could not dictate the measures taken by sporting organizations. However, since the Bosman judgment, the principles of the Treaty apply in their entirety to sport.

Does not the Commission consider it essential to consider the UEFA decision in the light of its compatibility with Community law (particularly Article 85 on freedom of competition) and to order that the measure be suspended until the Commission has given a ruling on the matter?

Answer

UEFA informed the Commission of the adoption of the rules to which the honourable Member refers. To date, the Commission has not been formally called upon to take a position with regard to the compatibility of these rules with Community law or, more particularly, with the EC Treaty"s rules of competition.

In its ruling of 15 December 1995 on the Bosman Affair(10) , the Court of Justice stated that, given the considerable social importance of sporting activity – especially football – within the Community, it was appropriate to recognize that the objectives of assuring that a balance is maintained between clubs by preserving a certain equality of opportunity and uncertainty in results, as well as encouraging the recruitment and training of young players was legitimate.

It initially seems that the rules in question are of a sporting nature and serve to guarantee one of the legitimate objectives recognized by the Court, that is, the uncertainty of results. It remains to be determined whether the adopted rules are limited to the means strictly needed to attain this objective or whether less restrictive methods exist.

The assessment of the compatibility of the behaviour of a business or group of businesses with the EC Treaty"s rules of competition can only be made with full knowledge of the facts within their particular economic and legal context. At the current moment, the Commission is not in possession of all the factors enabling it to proceed to a final assessment, particularly with regard to the issue of whether the UEFA rules go beyond what is necessary to guarantee the uncertainty of results in international competitions.

Given these conditions, the Commission is not able to impose a delay on the application of these rules. It believes in the good sense of sporting organizations and clubs to find appropriate solutions.

Question No 93 by Mihail Papayannakis (H−0662/98)

Subject: Operational programme for tourism and culture

The Greek operational programme for tourism and culture was amended on 7 December 1997.

Will the Commission say why it was deemed necessary to amend this programme, what kind of amendments were made to the programme and what is the take‐up rate so far – as well as the scheduled take‐up rate – for the subprogramme on tourism from the ESF whose contribution amounts to some ECU 10 000 000?

Answer

Within the framework of the mid‐term review, the Follow‐Up Committee for the Community support framework for Greece decided to transfer 6 billion drachma (around ECU 20 million) from the “Tourism’ subprogramme, partly because of a relative under‐utilization of appropriations provided for this subprogramme and partly because of the need for further appropriations in the other programmes. With regard to the “Culture’ subprogramme, it was decided to remove the budget for the “Acropolis Museum’ project since the Greek authorities had found sources of funding elsewhere.

With regard to initiatives undertaken with the European Regional Development Fund, the current take‐up rate for the operational programme for tourism and culture stands at 62 % for commitment appropriations and 27 % for payment appropriations. For initiatives undertaken with the European Social Fund, these rates are 13 % and 6.5 % respectively, which gives an overall take‐up rate of 60 % and 26 %.

Question No 94 by Paul Lannoye (H−0664/98)

Subject: EU‐USA Agreement

In an annex to the document of 18 May entitled 'Understanding with respect to disciplines for the strengthening of investment protection', in the context of the EU‐USA Agreement, Commissioner Brittan, on behalf of the Commission, advocated the application of paragraph IB2 of the agreement in the case of the expropriations which took place in Cuba (law No 851), which the Commissioner considered to be contrary to international law.

Does not the Commission consider that the adoption of this position effectively ruled out any resumption of action against the USA before the WTO in the Helms‐Burton case? Does not the Commission consider that the agreement as it stands should be submitted to the European Parliament before its entry into force?

Answer

The side‐letter annexed to the Community/US Understanding with respect to disciplines for the strengthening of investment protection of 18 May 1998 contains no legal judgment on any case or cases in Cuba. It merely states that ‚having regard to the discriminatory provisions of Cuban Law 851, it appears that the expropriations were contrary to international law’. This law which was enacted in July 1960 expropriated property or companies owned by US nationals, including Cuban corporations in which US nationals held interests. It is well established in international law that expropriations should not be carried out on a discriminatory basis and there is therefore cause to doubt the international legality of these expropriations. However, the expropriation of property held by US nationals was also carried out by other laws, some of which may not necessarily constitute a violation of international law.

The side‐letter is certainly not a condemnation of Cuban expropriations or an endorsement of US claims against Cuba. The purpose of the side‐letter is simply to assure the US that Community national investment support agencies are aware of the need to apply a heightened scrutiny when they are presented with future requests for investment support for projects in Cuba. The final determination of whether a particular property in Cuba was expropriated in violation of international law, and thus whether the disciplines enumerated in paragraph IB2 of the Understanding, will remain a matter for the national agencies in question.

In spite of this Understanding, the Commission's position of the Helms‐Burton Act remains that it is contrary to international law. At no point in time did the Community acknowledge the legitimacy of this Act. The Community has fully reserved its right to resume the WTO case in the event of action being taken against Community persons or companies under this Act.

As to the nature of the Understanding, it should be noted that it is of a political nature and not a legal document. The Understanding foresees, however, that the Community and the US will make a joint proposal in the Multilateral Agreement on Investment, incorporating the terms of the Understanding, which upon entry into force, will be an agreement binding under international law. Any agreement reached on a Multilateral Agreement on Investment would be subject to normal Community procedures, at the appropriate time.

Question No 95 by Edgar Schiedermeier (H−0665/98)

Subject: Call for applications under the ODYSSEUS programme

Does the Commission believe it is acting according to the principles of closeness to the citizen, equality of opportunity and transparency when it issues a call for applications under the Odysseus programme in which the deadline for their receipt is 5 June 1998, one day after its publication in the Official Journal of 4 June 1998?

Answer

The Commission was compelled to face up to two contradictory imperatives with regard to this cooperation programme on asylum, immigration and external borders.

On the one hand, the adoption of a common action, originally anticipated at the December 1997 Council, was delayed due to the opposition of certain Member States and was not able to be implemented until 19 March 1998.

On the other hand, the Council expressed a desire to see a rapid implementation of the programme in order to respond in particular to the needs relating to current issues and especially the Iraq action plan.

The Commission then drew up a draft annual programme which it submitted to members of the committee on 21 April 1998. The programme was adopted unanimously by the 15 Member States represented. The Commission then proceeded to the selection procedure at short notice. Demands of the calendar and workload on the part of some departments delayed the publication of the annual programme by two to three weeks, which led to the situation described by the honourable Member for the first date for submission of projects.

Whilst this situation is not entirely satisfactory, the Commission nevertheless does not consider that it constitutes an excessive attack on the equal opportunities of the project holders. Indeed, for the first phase of selection, the Commission has recorded the filing of 39 projects, of which almost half (18) come from non‐governmental organizations. These organizations had expressed their interest in the programme since the publication of the common action on 31 March 1998. Furthermore, the Selection Committee which met on 5 July 1998 took this situation into account by leaving substantial funds available for projects to be submitted to the second Selection Committee.

Question No 96 by Vassilis Ephremidis (H−0669/98)

Subject: Threat of environmental disaster on the island of Gavdopoula on the southern shores of Crete

One of the last rich ecosystems in Europe, the island of Gavdopoula on the southern shores of Crete, is threatened with ecological rape, since a large‐scale investor who has so far remained 'anonymous' plans to set up an industrial unit for the production, repair and transit of metal containers on the island. The study which has been submitted to the Greek Ministry for the Environment, Regional Planning and Public Works for approval provides for the construction of industrial facilities and buildings and fuel tanks – both floating and on dry land – to supply ships. In order to realize this controversial investment project it will be necessary to level the island, thereby causing irreparable damage to the ecosystem and the appearance of the island.

Given that the Gavdos‐Gavdopoula group of islands is included in the European Programme 'Natura 2000' which protects Europe's major ecosystems, and that the region is an important stopping‐off point for migratory birds and one of the richest fishing grounds in southern Europe and given also that the region of Gavdos is full of archaeological finds, will the Commission say what measures it intends to take to prevent this valuable biotope being turned into a polluted industrial site and to protect it effectively so that it is developed in a suitable manner?

Answer

A Site of Community Importance comprising the islands of Gavdos and Gavdopoula has been proposed by the Hellenic authorities pursuant to Directive 92/43/EEC(11) to be included in the European ecological network Natura 2000. In particular, this site hosts a number of priority habitats and species and their deterioration or disturbance should be avoided in view of the future inclusion of the site into the Natura 2000 network.

The Commission is aware of the facts stated by the honourable Member and has inquired about the matter; according to information transmitted by the Hellenic authorities, the Environmental Impact Assessment study for the project in question has not been approved by the Ministry of Environment. Furthermore, the Commission will seek additional and precise information from the Hellenic authorities in order to establish whether the conservation objectives of the site are respected and what measures are taken to avoid its degradation.

Question No 97 by Karl Habsburg‐Lothringen (H−0672/98)

Subject: JRC registration as a condition for participating in PHARE and other programmes

Participation in PHARE and other programmes requires JRC registration. For small and medium‐sized businesses this constitutes an almost insurmountable obstacle, not least because of the red tape involved in supplying the documentation necessary for registration, for which the numerous documents required have to be supplied in a specified form, i.e. through data media. This arrangement clearly favours large companies, which are more likely to have the requisite documentation and the relevant software at their disposal. Small and medium‐sized businesses, however, particularly those in their start‐up phase, are scarcely likely to have documentation about previously implemented projects at their disposal. The JRC registration requirement necessary for the submission of projects thus in itself constitutes a kind of pre‐selection, even before specific proposals and submissions can be assessed.

Does the Commission think that such de facto pre‐selection is helpful for the implementation of the relevant programmes? Is this de facto discrimination against small and medium‐sized businesses as a result of the JRC registration procedure requirement compatible with the Community's policy on the promotion of small and medium‐sized enterprises (the SME policy)? Does not this type of pre‐selection constitute discrimination against the new Member States, which are unable to refer to previously implemented projects?

Answer

1. The register of consultants, managed by the Directorate‐General for External Relations: Europe and NIS, CFSP, external department for the PHARE, TACIS and Obnova programmes, is an important management tool which contributes to increased transparency in the allocation of markets within the framework of these programmes. Furthermore, the Council regulations in question demand consultation of the register by the Commission"s departments.

2. DG IA requested the firms concerned to provide the necessary information as a priority by E‐mail, a method which enormously facilitates the handling of the dossier by the Commission and the firm in question. It is, nevertheless, still possible to send the necessary information on paper, if the company in question is unable or unwilling to use a data carrier.

3. JRC registration is thus not a form of preselection and does not prevent access by small and medium‐sized enterprises; in fact it gives the different Commission departments the opportunity of familiarizing themselves with a company, its capacities and its future interests.

If JRC did not exist, small and medium‐sized enterprises would probably have more difficulty in accessing the Commission"s markets.

Question No 98 by María Izquierdo Rojo (H−0675/98)

Subject: Need for effective policies to prevent the deaths of Moroccan immigrants in makeshift rafts

In view of the appalling news of seven more deaths in addition to the previous deaths of large numbers of illegal immigrants in makeshift rafts in the Straits of Gibraltar, the fact that the EU is not making every endeavour to put an end to this waste of human life as a matter of urgency and the fact there is a new government in the Kingdom of Morocco, what joint actions – campaigns, measures or policies – will be adopted in the immediate future?

Answer

The Commission deeply regrets the tragedy which has again occurred in the Straits of Gibraltar, and the loss of human life involved.

The Commission does not have the means to stop the illegal immigration of Moroccans into the Community, in particular Spain. Although this question currently comes under issues of common interest according to Title VI of the Treaty on European Union, in this specific case it is largely for the Spanish and Moroccan governments to put in place the means for preventing a repetition of such occurrences.

In the medium term, it is by fighting underdevelopment, which is at the root of illegal immigration, that the European Union and Morocco will be able to prevent the repetition of such tragedies.

Question No 99 by Gerard Collins (H−0678/98)

Subject: Combatting illegal drugs crops

Can the Commission indicate what measures it is taking actively to promote policies of crop substitution in those countries where farmers have been tempted to grow crops for the illegal drugs trade and does the Commission accept that crop substitution initiatives can actively assist in the campaign to control illegal drug abuse?

Answer

The promotion of alternative development is one of the instruments used by the European Community to assist developing countries in their fight to reduce, and eventually eliminate, the cultivation, production and trafficking of cocaine, heroin and cannabis. Under appropriate conditions, which include the political commitment to eradication on the part of both the country's authorities and the populations concerned, alternative development can be an effective instrument in the fight against drugs.

Alternative development is a broader concept than crop substitution as it implies that the direct stimulus, for shifting cultivation patterns from narcotic plants to licit crops, must be accompanied by a set of complementary socioeconomic conditions and efforts that ensure the sustainability of development in the regions concerned. For instance, infrastructures such as roads, storage facilities and distribution channels must exist or need to be created so that licit crops can reach their markets timely. Sufficient demand, whether domestic or foreign, for the replacement crops must also be evident, be identified through market research and, eventually, encouraged through appropriate marketing efforts.

The Commission is currently supporting alternative development projects in Latin America (Bolivia) and Northern Africa (Morocco). In the past, it also did so in Lebanon.

As regards Latin America, the Community is supporting a major project for the Chaparé and surrounding regions for a total of ECU 30m. The Commission is contemplating now the financing of a similar project in Peru, in the case a request is put forward by Peru on the framework the joint Consultative Committee on days that will take place in November. In parallel, two important alternative development projects are being financed for Morocco's Northern region (the Rif), in order to reduce its economic and social dependence on cannabis cultivation.

In addition to the financing of cooperation projects, the special drug‐fighting related trade preferences, granted to Central America and the Andean countries within the Community's Generalised Preferences Scheme, also play a significant role in facilitating the diversification of these two regions away from coca cultivation and cocaine production and trafficking.

Question No 100 by Niall Andrews (H−0680/98)

Subject: Urban redevelopment

Can the Commission indicate what plans, if any, it has to promote the regeneration and redevelopment of run down areas in our cities and what plans, if any, it has to promote cooperation between urban areas in finding solutions to common problems which exist in depressed areas in many urban areas of Europe such as high unemployment, social exclusion, poor quality housing, crime and drug abuse?

Answer

The Commission, over the years, has supported innovative and integrated approaches to the regeneration of run down urban areas through the urban pilot projects promoted under Article 10 of the European Regional Development Fund Regulation(12) and through the URBAN Community Initiative. Building on this successful experience, Agenda 2000 proposes that in the next programming period and for the first time, mainstream Objective 2 programmes can be targeted towards urban areas in difficulty.

The Commission's new proposals for Community Initiatives and innovative actions are not yet sufficiently advanced to clarify the extent of potential action in urban areas. However, the Commission is preparing a follow up document to last year's Communication ‚Towards an urban agenda in the European Union’. The new document will take the form of an Action Plan that will propose ways in which the Community can take more effective action in urban areas, including through a more integrated approach to the serious problems mentioned by the honourable Member.

Question No 101 by Liam Hyland (H−0681/98)

Subject: 'Heritage towns'

The Commission has been supporting the preservation and protection of the architectural heritage of many of our towns through Structural Fund programmes such as that used to assist the 'Heritage Towns' programme in Ireland.

Can the Commission indicate if such projects will continue to qualify for Structural Fund assistance and the AGENDA 2000 proposals, bearing in mind that these programmes have had tremendous positive benefits in the affected communities, both in terms of improving the environment and in developing tourism and related industries?

Answer

The Commission has emphasized in its Communication on ‚Cohesion Policy and Culture – A contribution to employment’(13) the important role which cultural heritage can play in sustainable regional development.

The Structural Funds will continue assisting the preservation and protection of the architectural heritage where this contributes to local or regional development strategies or the creation of jobs. The new Structural Funds Regulations will, under the Commission's proposals, leave the related eligibility criteria unchanged.

However, the question whether programmes such as ‚Heritage Towns’ will continue to be included in Irish Operational Programmes remains to be considered in subsequent negotiations with the Member State.

Question No 102 by James Fitzsimons (H−0682/98)

Subject: Buildings and pollution

As the Commission is aware, up to 75 % of the buildings needed in most developed countries over the next 50 years have already been built. Furthermore, despite the concern about the level of road traffic pollution, it is estimated that buildings, in fact, account for about half the total man‐made CO2 emissions.

Will the Commission explain, in the light of the need to meet Kyoto emissions reduction targets, how it considers, as a matter of urgent EU policy, CO2 emissions from buildings can be eliminated and to what extent it will give priority to promoting and resourcing public buildings, new and old, which are capable of generating their own renewable energy through wind, water and the sun and how can the EU assist Ireland in pursuing such an objective?

Answer

The Commission agrees that, in order to meet the targets for greenhouse gases agreed in Kyoto, it will be necessary to take further action to reduce the CO2 emission requirements of existing buildings.

Under the subsidiarity principle, buildings policy is primarily a matter for Member States. Nevertheless as part of the SAVE programme (now in its second phase(14) ), the Community adopted ‚Council Directive 93/76/EEC to limit carbon dioxide emissions by improving energy efficiency’. This requires Member States to implement programmes in six areas, four of which relate specifically to buildings. In addition, the Community has been active in promoting energy efficiency of the equipment used in buildings, notably for boilers, refrigerators and freezers. Furthermore a compulsory energy labelling scheme has been set up under Directive 92/75/EEC covering a range of household appliances.

In addition numerous pilot projects financed under both the SAVE and ALTENER programmes have sought to increase energy efficiency and the use of renewable energy sources in existing buildings. In Ireland these include two projects dealing with energy rating of existing buildings, two which help local authorities to improve the efficiency of their housing and other building stock, and two which deal with passive solar design.

Notwithstanding these existing initiatives, the Community and the Member States will need to take further common and coordinated measures in order to meet the Kyoto targets.
