The action plan in the White Paper ‚Energy for the future: renewable sources of energy’(15) included proposed measures to promote the use of renewable energy in buildings, in particular photovoltaics, and the amendment of Directive 93/76 to promote active and passive solar systems in buildings. Following the Commission's Communication ‚Energy Efficiency in the European Community – Towards a Strategy for the Rational Use of Energy’ the forthcoming action plan on energy efficiency will also include measures to strengthen Directive 93/76 in the field of energy efficiency of existing buildings, and in particular to promote high standards of energy efficiency in building renovation.

Furthermore during the period 1994‐1999 the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) is supporting, with a total amount of ECU 19.7m, the deployment of energy efficient technology awareness campaigns on the efficient use of energy.

In order to reduce the dependence on fossil fuels the ERDF is also supporting investment in renewable energy schemes with grant support of ECU 18.6m.

Question No 103 by Robert Evans (H−0683/98)

Subject: Development funding and environmental concerns

Would the Commission clarify the environmental criteria used when awarding funds for development projects?

Several of my constituents have expressed disquiet over reports of projects which receive European funding and which, whilst they might be of some short‐term benefit to the local population, may in fact be adding to environmental deterioration in the region. An infrastructure project to improve road access in Cameroon has been mentioned specifically in this context.

Answer

Since the introduction of the Environment Manual in 1993 each project proposal is subject to an environmental screening. Through the screening process it will be identified whether negative environmental impacts can be expected due to the implementation of the project. If this is the case, the project proposal has to undergo a preliminary environmental impact study or, in case that a serious negative impact is likely, a full environmental impact study has to be conducted. The results of such an independent study will either conclude that the impacts are so serious that the project should not be funded or it will identify specific measures in order to mitigate the expected negative environmental impacts.

If required, a copy of the Environmental Manual can be made available.

The Commission is aware of criticism concerning an ‚EC funded road’ in Cameroon. This criticism has been brought up by the Rainforest Foundation through a film shown on a UK TV channel about a so‐called ‚EC aid scandal – logging and bushmeat trade’. The film suggests the existence of a causal link between the construction of a ECU 14m EC funded road through primary rainforest and negative effects such as the destruction of this forest through logging and the extermination of endangered species through intensive poaching, thus depriving the local pygmies of their livelihood.

Facts are quite different. The EC funded maintenance works on an existing road for ECU 0.6m. This road is the only access for the remote Lomié district and its farming population, which outnumbers by far the Pygmy hunters; it is of vital importance for this population.

The Rainforest Foundation never checked with the Commission the information provided by their own sources. They would have learned inter alia about various ongoing projects for the conservation of the local fauna and, more generally, sustainable development of forestry resources, projects financed by the EC in the Cameroonian rainforest area.

Question No 104 by Mark Killilea (H−0693/98)

Subject: Wild Birds Directive

The Commission recently forwarded reasoned opinions to Ireland for infringements of the Directive on the Conservation of Wild Birds (79/409/EEC)(16) , arising out of its failure to protect the Owenduff‐Nephin Beg Special Protection Area in County Mayo, a habitat of rare species such as the Greenland White‐fronted Goose and the Golden Plover, as well as its failure to protect other areas that are the habitat of the Red Grouse, one of Ireland's most threatened bird species.

Can the Commission inform me as to what action Ireland has since taken to meet the requirements of the Directive, or what timescale has been given to comply with same.

Answer

The honourable Member is correct: the Commission notified a Reasoned Opinion to Ireland on this matter in April 1998, allowing two months for Ireland to respond.

On 3 June 1998, the Irish authorities requested an additional two months to respond in detail. As a result, the Commission has deferred taking a further decision on the legal action until later this year.

As Ireland's detailed response is not yet available, the Commission is unable to comment on any action taken by Ireland to deal with the issues raised in the Reasoned Opinion. The Commission might also mention that no response was received to its Letter of Formal Notice, which preceded the Reasoned Opinion.

Question No 105 by Aline Pailler (H−0694/98)

Subject: Retail price controls on books

The Commission's passion for deregulation seems to know no bounds. On the pretext of ensuring compliance with competition rules, it has initiated proceedings covering cross‐border agreements on book prices. The Commission's real intention is, however, to challenge the system of retail price controls on books, which, among other things, enables literary production to be promoted and small bookshops to survive.

Instead of attacking an arrangement which ensures diversity of choice for book‐buyers, might not the Commission do better to propose that the system of retail price controls be extended to all the Member States?

Answer

The honourable Member asserts that retail price controls on books “enable literary production to be promoted and small bookshops to survive’. The benefit of the system of price controls in relation to these objectives was put forward as an argument in the Commission procedures, but this latter had precisely commenced the procedure in the two cases in which there was modification of demand between Member States because this usefulness had not, at that time, been concretely proven. Nor had it been demonstrated that other less restrictive competition measures were impossible. Furthermore, the Commission has not challenged the system of price controls which has no impact on trade. In the case of France, for example, the Commission obtained an improvement in the system as it had no impact on trade, a position which was reinforced by the Court of Justice (Leclerc ruling).

The Commission also notes that there would probably not be a sufficient majority for a possible proposal for a directive extending the system of price controls on books to all of the Member States. In fact, there has long been division on this issue.

Finally, the introduction of the euro and the arrival of electronic shopping for books should bring about greater choice for the European consumer, as well as more competitive prices.

Question No 106 by Nel van Dijk (H−0697/98)

Subject: Cessation of the carriage of bicycles on international trains in France

Without any fanfare of publicity the French railways have put a halt to the carriage of bicycles as special luggage on international trains this summer. There are no acceptable alternatives such as other forms of dispatch or the possibility of taking bicycles as accompanying luggage on international trains. This decision by the SNCF is to be seen as a rejection of the Commission, Council and Parliament's clearly expressed concern for both sustainable mobility and sustainable tourism in the EU, and merits the severest condemnation.

Is the Commission aware of this step, and what action does it intend to take to enable bicycles to be carried on international trains throughout the European Union?

Answer

The Commission believes that there are two appropriate ways to encourage the carriage of bicycles on trains. First, public authorities may include requirements to accept bicycles when they specify public services to be provided by operators. It is for authorities in Member States to define these services.

Second, the Commission wishes to encourage train operators to carry bicycles where this is in their own commercial interests. It is for operators to judge where this is the case. Through its policies to promote the Citizens' Network, the Commission aims to help make these cases more common. A specific example is its decision to provide grant‐aid for the planning phase of the Euro Velo international cycle routes project. One of the main objectives of this project is to promote cycle tourism. This should increase the demand for transport of cycles by train to key points on each cycle route.

The Commission is currently managing a research cooperation project on passengers' accessibility of heavy rail systems (COST 335). While the focus of the project is the needs of people with reduced mobility, it is likely that many of the train design features examined will also benefit people with bicycles.

Question No 107 by Brian Crowley (H−0699/98)

Subject: Enlargement and low‐wage competition from the East

One of the issues raised about the enlargement process relates to low‐wage competition from the East.

Has the Commission examined this question in any detail and, if so, what are the results and, if not, will the Commission undertake the appropriate analysis as a matter of urgency on a sectoral basis?

Answer

The Commission has indeed examined this question, in the study ‚The effects on the Union's policies of enlargement to the applicant countries of central and eastern Europe (Impact Study)’, which the Commission published as part of the Agenda 2000 package in July 1997.

The study concludes that the economic effects of enlargement will undoubtedly be beneficial for the Community in the longer run. These benefits will not be instantaneous or evenly spread. Substantial adjustment pressure at the sectoral and regional level will be unavoidable. Yet, independently of enlargement, the Community will need to change anyway, because of such forces as globalization, the changed world trade order, emergence of new and competitive producer countries etc. In that sense, enlargement should be regarded as a development of tendencies which are already present, rather than an imposition of new stresses on the Community economy.

It should also be pointed out that the economic impact of eastern enlargement will not be felt abruptly on the day of accession: the Europe Agreements already provide for substantial and progressive integration, and in the most sensitive areas transitional periods may be negotiated for the first years after accession. Wage differentials between the Community and the candidate countries are large today, but they are offset at least in part by considerable differences in labour productivity, and they are likely to be reduced quite rapidly as the applicant countries' economies catch up with the Community and their real exchange rates appreciate.

Question No 108 by Manuel Medina Ortega (H−0700/98)

Subject: Regeneration of Portman Bay and Escombreras dock (Murcia, Spain)

With reference to the statements by the President of the Murcia Regional Government to the effect that the extension of the docks at Escombreras and the regeneration of Portman Bay 'will come about when the funds requested from the European Union are granted', can the Commission provide information concerning the amount of funding in question and the stage reached in the processing of the application?

Answer

The Spanish authorities announced the introduction of a project concerning the regeneration of Portman Bay, with a view to its being cofinanced by the Cohesion Fund. Nevertheless, to date the Commission has received no request for funding of the project in question. It is thus unable to comment with regard to the amount of funding provided in this respect.

The project relating to the extension of the docks at Escombreras is cofinanced neither by the Cohesion Fund nor by the European Regional Development Fund.

Question No 109 by Alan Gillis (H−0701/98)

Subject: EU environment legislation – Dumps

Now that the Irish Parliament has adopted legislation requiring municipal authorities to apply for a waste licence from the Irish Environmental Protection Agency and that the Commission has therefore decided to abandon its legal action against Ireland on the issue of the lack of provision for waste permits, does the Commission intend to deal with those sites where work has already begun illegally in spite of public protest and where licences will be issued retrospectively to cover those councils who acted without going to the IEPA for a licence prior to the adoption of the above legislation or will the Commission just wash its hands of this situation?

Answer

It is assumed that the honourable Member is referring to a long‐standing concern which the Commission has had about the absence of formal provision for waste permits for municipal waste facilities in Irish legislation. According to the Community's Framework Waste Directive (Directive 75/442/EEC on waste(17) ), such facilities should have a permit. This weakness in the Irish legislation prompted the Commission to take action against Ireland under Article 169 of the Treaty.

However, in 1997, Ireland adopted new national legislation dealing with the matter. For practical reasons, permits (or licences as they are referred to in Ireland) were to be introduced gradually between 1997 and 1999, with new facilities and larger facilities being dealt with first and smaller facilities later. In response to this new legislation, the Commission terminated its legal action.

As regards municipal facilities which came into being or were partially developed before the new national legislation became operative, the Commission considers that, in general, it would now be inappropriate to take any legal action under Article 169 on the sole ground of lack of a permit, given the measures taken to regularise matters. However, there may be other issues of compliance with Community environmental law involved where a development has taken place in the circumstances mentioned by the honourable Member. Much depends on the specific circumstances.

Question No 110 by Jan Bertens (H−0706/98)

Subject: The situation in Mexico

Recently I have been receiving critical reports about the situation in Mexico suggesting that the Mexican authorities have launched a large‐scale offensive in Chiapas.

Can the Commission obtain information about the situation in Mexico? Did the Commission (and the Council) bring this matter up at the opening of the Joint Council on 13‐14 July? If so, what was the outcome of the discussion?

Can the Commission given an undertaking to draw up annual reports on the situation with regard to human rights and democracy in Mexico, as called for by many MEPs during the consideration of the interim agreement?

What impact will the degree of compliance with the democracy and human rights clause by the Mexican authorities have on the further negotiations concerning the framework agreement?

Answer

The Commission has noted the recent developments in the situation in Chiapas. Some of them, such as the recent expulsions of European nationals or the recent clashes between Zapatista communities and military forces in Chiapas, are extremely disturbing. At the same time, the initiative taken by the Mexican authorities to introduce modifications to the Mexican Constitution in order to find a lasting and peaceful solution to the problem is a source of hope for the long‐term future of the region.

At this stage, it is still too early to provide the honourable Member with information on the progress of the first meeting of the Joint Council with Mexico, which is expected to be held on 14 July. However, the Commission notes that an exchange of views on the situation in Chiapas was the main theme of the meeting between the EU Troika and Mexico at the last meeting of the Rio Group in Panama in February 1998. This meeting enabled the Mexican Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mrs Rosario Green, to give a detailed statement on the efforts initiated by the government in order to improve the situation in Chiapas.

With regard to the information requested by the honourable Member concerning the human rights situation, the Commission will use all existing means, as it always has done in the past, to continue to inform Parliament regularly on this subject, on the basis of the contacts it maintains with the different representatives of civil society, including NGOs and human rights groups, which provide a substantial amount of information on the country. This information, which comes primarily from international sources, Member States" missions and the Commission"s delegation on the ground, enables an appropriate assessment of the situation with regard to respect for human rights in the country.

The Interim Agreement signed between the Community and Mexico on 8 December 1997, which was the subject of the assent of the European Parliament last May, is based on respect for democratic principles and human rights, which inspires the policies and constitutes an essential factor in relations between the parties.

It came into effect on 1 July 1998 and this constitutes a very significant stage in as far as the agreement, which includes clauses regarding respect for human rights, creates a legal framework enabling better consideration of this problem, in order to contribute more effectively and constructively to an improvement in the situation of Mexico in this respect.

Question No 111 by Joan Colom I Naval (H−0709/98)

Subject: Reasons for the poor implementation of the LEADER Community Initiative

According to the most recent figures for implementation of the Community Initiatives, only a very low percentage of the appropriations allocated to Spain for the LEADER Community Initiative were used in 1996 and 1997.

Can the Commission state the reasons for this low rate of utilization of the appropriations? To what extent is the Commission or the Member State in question to blame? If matters continue in the same way this year, how much money could Spain lose?

Answer

An analysis of the data relating to the implementation of the FEDER II regional programmes in Spain at the end of 1997 shows a significant delay in relation to the initial forecasts. In fact, the average level of commitments carried out between the local action groups and the final beneficiaries (instigators of the project), as at the end of 1997, comes to 37 % of provisions for the programme period 1994‐1999. Nevertheless, this indicator shows very significant variations between the different regional programmes and between different groups within each regional programme.

In addition, this delay must be put into context for, on the one hand, approval of the LEADER II programmes by the Commission took place in July 1995 and, on the other hand, the process of starting up (selection of local action groups, communication with potential beneficiaries of aid) was very slow.

The Commission has made known its concern with regard to the slow rhythm of implementation of LEADER II programmes to the Spanish authorities and has sent them a letter requesting that they speed up the implementation of this Community initiative. The Spanish authorities have stated that the local action groups are actively implementing their plans for rural innovation at this current time and they have declared themselves convinced that the programmes will be concluded before the end of the programme period. This conviction has been expressed both by central government and by the governments of the autonomous communities during meetings of the Follow‐Up Committee which recently took place. Thus for the intermediary organization (Ministry of Agriculture and Department of Agriculture of the regional governments), the commitments between the local action groups and the instigators of the project can be carried out before 31 December 1999.

The intermediary organization envisages studying the achievements of the different groups within each regional programme at the end of 1998 and, if need be, will proceed to strengthen the finances allocated to the most advanced groups to the detriment of those who are extremely behind, with the aim of being able to commit all of the appropriations allocated to each programme before the end of 1999.

It is appropriate to mention in this respect that payments can be made until the end of 2001.

Question No 112 by Christine Oddy (H−0716/98)

Subject: Driving courses for disabled people and people with learning difficulties

What are the provisions in the Member States for encouraging disabled people and people with learning difficulties to drive? What steps has the Commission taken to encourage these people to drive? Would the Commission consider the need to establish a European Driving Centre for Disabled People?

Answer

There are no Community provisions that relate specifically to driving courses for disabled persons or for persons with learning difficulties. In line with the principle of subsidiarity, this matter is left to the discretion of the Member States. The European Commission cannot, therefore, consider the setting up of a European Driving Centre for Disabled People.

Two provisions do, however, serve indirectly to facilitate driving by disabled persons:

‐ The Council has adopted a Recommendation on the reciprocal recognition of a parking card for people with disabilities based on a standardised Community model.

(18)

‐ Under the provisions of Directive 97/26/EC(19) amending directive 91/439/EEC(20) on driving licences, the use of codes and subcodes to indicate car adaptations make driving licences more easily understood and mutually recognisable and thereby facilitate the free movement of disabled persons.

Question No 113 by Nikolaos Papakyriazis (H−0718/98)

Subject: Desecration of a Greek Orthodox cemetery

On 2 April 1998 I tabled a question (H−0425/98) to the Commission on the desecration of the Greek Orthodox cemetery of Aghios Eleftherios in Istanbul on 1 April 1998.

On 12 May I received a written reply from the Commission condemning this act of vandalism and stating that it would ask the Turkish authorities to take appropriate measures and condemn this act.

Will the Commission now say precisely what action it has taken in this connection and, above all, what the response of the Turkish Government has been?

Answer

Since the question raised by the honourable Member last April regarding the deplorable act committed against the Eleftherios Greek Orthodox Cemetery in Istanbul, the Commission has continued to obtain information on the situation and has resumed contacts with the Turkish authorities in order to obtain information regarding the follow‐up provided by the latter with regard to these serious incidents.

The Turkish authorities have indicated to the Commission that they strongly condemned this act in a declaration made on 4 April 1998 by the Turkish Foreign Affairs Ministry:

This declaration stated that:

’It has regretfully been confirmed that on 31 March 1998, unidentified persons, entering the Greek Orthodox Graveyard located at Bayir Street in the Kurtulus Municipality in Istanbul, have uncovered some graves and caused damage to these graves during their action.

Turkey condemns any such appalling actions, which run contrary to our moral values, wherever they may occur. It is only natural that all efforts will be resolutely exerted to bring to justice the perpetrators of this crime and to prevent recurrences of this kind’.

Question No 114 by Ioannis Theonas (H−0721/98)

Subject: US aid for the self‐styled Kosovo Liberation Army

Following the meeting between Mr Holbrooke and representatives of the guerrillas of the self‐styled Kosovo Liberation Army another official meeting has taken place, this time between 'KLA' representatives and the US special envoy to the Balkans who has claimed that the 'guerrillas' must be involved in the search for a solution in Kosovo.

Given that the self‐styled Kosovo Liberation Army seeks the secession of Kosovo from Serbia and the new Yugoslavia, which would involve border changes and pose a risk of a more widespread conflict throughout the Balkans, will the Commission say whether it condemns this US position which is exacerbating tension and inciting armed conflict in the Balkans, and whether it disapproves of the statements by the American envoys about the need to involve the self‐styled Kosovo Liberation Army in the search for a solution? Does it not agree that these actions and statements militate against and hinder a peaceful political solution to the Kosovo crisis?

Answer

Regarding concerns about the Kosovo Liberation Army's (KLA) claim for secession from the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, the Commission recalls the long‐standing position of the EU and the international community of ‚firm opposition to independence’, while continuing to support ‚a special status, including a large degree of autonomy for Kosovo, within the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.’

As far as contacts with Kosovo Albanians are concerned, the Commission shares the view of the international community that there is an urgent need for progress towards a negotiated settlement, including the valiant efforts by the US which aims to broker a cease‐fire in order to create the conditions for the restart of negotiations. As part of this endeavour talks took place with KLA contacts. The Commission also supports the statement of the Council on 29 June that ‚all those in a leadership role in the Kosovo Albania community should unite responsibly in making clear their commitment to dialogue and a peaceful resolution of the problems of Kosovo, and their rejection of violence and acts of terrorism’.

The Commission furthermore notes that a peaceful political solution to resolve the crisis will also require the withdrawal by Belgrade of the security forces from Kosovo, a demand made by the European Council at Cardiff on 15 June but not yet met by President Milosevic.
